of Colorado","authoringStatusCode":"in_progress","primaryImage":{"createdPrincipalId":"up016bb0b82173860f","height":402,"cloudinaryVersionId":1396414680,"id":"ci01a8bfd5fa6e860b","objectType":"ContentPhoto","title":"Glenn-Miller-37990-1-402","primaryPhotoId":"ci01a8bfd5fa6e860b","hasFaces":true,"width":402,"publicId":"MTE5NDg0MDU0NjA2MjE4NzY3","format":"jpg","createdTimestamp":"2014-04-02T04:58:01Z","primaryContentSiteId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e","bytes":76683,"primarySiteId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e"},"vocabularyId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e:schools","editedByPrincipalId":"up016bb0b82173860f","editedTimestamp":"2014-04-02T04:58:05Z","disqusId":"600530fc-ba23-11e3-8061-002219604f34","originalPublicationTimestamp":"2014-04-02T04:55:07Z","createdTimestamp":"2014-04-02T04:58:05Z","versionId":"1","primaryImageId":"ci01a8bfd5fa6e860b","path":"/people/groups/famous-alumni-of-university-of-colorado","isWorkInProgress":false,"slug":"famous-alumni-of-university-of-colorado","displayName":"University States","authoringStatusCode":"in_progress","primaryImage":{"createdPrincipalId":"up016bb0b82173860f","height":402,"cloudinaryVersionId":1396412579,"id":"ci01a87e1d553f860f","objectType":"ContentPhoto","title":"Mildred-Loving-5884-1-402","primaryPhotoId":"ci01a87e1d553f860f","hasFaces":true,"width":402,"publicId":"MTE1ODA0OTcxMjQ4NzQ4MDQ1","format":"jpg","createdTimestamp":"2014-04-02T04:23:00Z","primaryContentSiteId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e","bytes":85862,"primarySiteId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e"},"vocabularyId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e:death_country","editedByPrincipalId":"up016bb0b82173860f","editedTimestamp":"2014-04-02T04:23:04Z","disqusId":"5da6a96c-ba1e-11e3-be79-002219604f34","originalPublicationTimestamp":"2014-04-02T04:19:16Z","createdTimestamp":"2014-04-02T04:23:04Z","versionId":"2","primaryImageId":"ci01a87e1d553f860f","path":"/people/groups/died-in-united-states","isWorkInProgress":false,"slug":"died-in-united-states","displayName":"United States","primaryContentSiteId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e","promoTitle":"Famous People Who Died in United States","primarySiteId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e","statusCode":"complete"},"birthCirca":false,"birthMonth":"12","metaDescription":"Dalton Trumbo was an award-winning author and screenwriter who was blacklisted from the film industry from 1947 until the early '60s due to his Communist ties. Learn more about his life and career at Biography.com.","editedTimestamp":"2016-02-18T20:16:15Z","deathState":{"publicationTimestamp":"2014-04-02T04:19:15Z","createdPrincipalId":"up016bb0b82173860f","commentsEnabled":true,"id":"ci019b6c01fe72860d","objectType":"ContentRichTerm","isNoindex":false,"title":"California","authoringStatusCode":"in_progress","primaryImage":{"createdPrincipalId":"up016bb0b82173860f","height":402,"cloudinaryVersionId":1396412777,"id":"ci01ac7ce9c0bc860c","objectType":"ContentPhoto","title":"Tom-Bosley-13228-1-402","primaryPhotoId":"ci01ac7ce9c0bc860c","hasFaces":true,"width":402,"publicId":"MTE5NDg0MDU0NTc3Nzc2MTQz","format":"jpg","createdTimestamp":"2014-04-02T04:26:18Z","primaryContentSiteId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e","bytes":77362,"primarySiteId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e"},"vocabularyId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e:death_state","editedByPrincipalId":"up016bb0b82173860f","editedTimestamp":"2014-04-02T04:26:21Z","disqusId":"5cb849b6-ba1e-11e3-9706-002219604f34","originalPublicationTimestamp":"2014-04-02T04:19:15Z","createdTimestamp":"2014-04-02T04:26:21Z","versionId":"2","primaryImageId":"ci01ac7ce9c0bc860c","path":"/people/groups/died-in-california","isWorkInProgress":false,"slug":"died-in-california","displayName":"California","primaryContentSiteId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e","promoTitle":"Famous People Who Died in California","primarySiteId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e","statusCode":"complete"},"authoringStatusCode":"complete","profileTml":"<!-- tml-version=\"2\" --><section><h2>Synopsis&nbsp;<\/h2><p>Famed author and screenwriter Dalton Trumbo was born on December 9, 1905, in Montrose, Colorado. After embarking on a successful career with Warner Bros., in 1947 Trumbo joined nine colleagues in refusing to testify before Congress regarding their Communist ties. The so-called \"Hollywood Ten\" were blacklisted from that time until the early 1960s. Trumbo died of a heart attack on September 10, 1976, in Los Angeles, California. &nbsp;<\/p><h2>Heading West&nbsp;<\/h2><p>James Dalton Trumbo was born in Montrose, Colorado, on December 9, 1905, the first son of shoe-store clerk Orus and his wife, Maud. When Trumbo was 3 years old, his family moved to nearby Grand Junction, where he would spend his youth. While attending high school there, he indulged an early interest in writing by working as a cub reporter for a local paper.&nbsp;<\/p><p>Trumbo continued his journalistic pursuits while attending the University of Colorado before leaving the state in 1925 to join his family, who had moved to Los Angeles after he graduated high school. When his father died the following year, Trumbo took a job in a bakery to help support his mother and younger sisters. He worked there for nearly 10 years while cranking out countless short stories and novels—none of which he could find a publisher for—attending the University of California and working several other odd jobs.&nbsp;<\/p><h2>A Prized Writer<\/h2><p>In the early 1930s, Trumbo began to write professionally, publishing articles and stories in magazines such as the <em>Saturday Evening Post<\/em>, <em>Vanity Fair<\/em> and the <em>Hollywood Spectator<\/em>. He became the managing editor of the <em>Spectator<\/em> in 1934, a year that also saw him publish his first novel, <em>Eclipse<\/em>, as well as land a job as a script reader in the Warner Bros. story department. Then in 1935 Trumbo signed a contract with the studio as a junior writer, launching what would prove to be a long—and complicated—career.&nbsp;<\/p><p>In 1936 Trumbo received his first screenwriting credit, specifically for the crime drama <em>Road Gang<\/em>, and over the course of the next 10 years became one of the most successful and sought after writers in Hollywood. Some highlights among his many credits are <em>A Man to Remember<\/em> (1938), the 1940 romantic drama <em>Kitty Foyle <\/em>(which starred <a href=\"http://www.biography.com/people/ginger-rogers-9462173\">Ginger Rogers<\/a> and earned Trumbo his first Academy Award nomination, for best adapted screenplay) and the highly lauded World War II drama <em>Thirty Seconds Over Tokyo<\/em> (1944), starring&nbsp;<a href=\"http://www.biography.com/people/spencer-tracy-9509626\">Spencer Tracy<\/a>&nbsp;and <a href=\"http://www.biography.com/people/robert-mitchum-9410558\">Robert Mitchum<\/a>.&nbsp;<\/p><p>During this time, Trumbo was finding success away from the studio as well. In 1939 he married Cleo Fincher, with whom he would have three children, and in September of that year he achieved his peak as a novelist with the antiwar story <em>Johnny Got His Gun<\/em>. The novel received a National Book Award and has been adapted numerous times for radio, stage and screen.&nbsp;<\/p><h2>Blacklisted&nbsp;<\/h2><p>Although the success of <em>Johnny Got His Gun<\/em>&nbsp;earned Trumbo notoriety as an author, the work eventually garnered him a fair share of unwanted attention as well. Like many intellectuals and artists at the time, Trumbo was a member of the Communist Party and during his career had frequently taken unpopular left-leaning political positions. But when he received fan letters from Nazi sympathizers who had misunderstood his intentions with <em>Johnny Got His Gun<\/em>, Trumbo reported them to the FBI. Rather than pursue the letter writers, however, the bureau opened an investigation of Trumbo.<\/p><blockquote tml-render-layout=\"inline\"><p><strong>\"The chief internal enemies of any state are those public officials who betray the trust imposed upon them by the people.\" - Dalton Trumbo<\/strong><\/p><\/blockquote><p>In October 1947, as postwar paranoia about the perceived threat of Communism was ramping up in the United States, Trumbo was among a group of 10 Hollywood directors and writers called to testify before the House Committee on Un-American Activities (HUAC), which was charged with investigating whether Communist sympathizers had propagandized American audiences. Trumbo and the other nine individuals summoned all refused to testify, and as a consequence, the “Hollywood Ten” were found guilty of contempt of Congress. They were subsequently blacklisted by the heads of the major studios, and in 1950 Trumbo served almost a year in prison.&nbsp;<\/p><h2>Robert Rich and Other Not-Trumbos&nbsp;<\/h2><p>Following his release, Trumbo was unable to find work in California and moved his family to Mexico City. From there, he continued to write screenplays, which he was able to sell by using either pseudonyms or other writers to act as fronts for his work. During this time, Trumbo wrote at least 10 screenplays that were made into films—including the 1953 classic <em>Roman Holiday<\/em>, starring <a href=\"http://www.biography.com/people/gregory-peck-9436049\">Gregory Peck<\/a> and <a href=\"http://www.biography.com/people/audrey-hepburn-9335788\">Audrey Hepburn<\/a>—as well as doing an unknown quantity of revision work on many others.&nbsp;<\/p><p>Finally, in 1957, after nearly a decade of working in exile, Trumbo at last saw an opportunity to return to Hollywood, when his screenplay for <em>The Brave One<\/em>—written under the pseudonym Robert Rich—received an Academy Award. When journalists were subsequently unable to find the mysterious Robert Rich for comment, it was soon surmised that the film had in fact been written by Trumbo. This and other similar incidents involving blacklisted writers led to a general reexamination of the practice, with support for the concept quickly weakening in the industry.&nbsp;<\/p><p>The year after “Robert Rich” won the Oscar for<em> The Brave One<\/em>, Trumbo was hired to write the adaptation for the&nbsp;best-selling&nbsp;novel about the creation of Israel,&nbsp;<em>Exodus<\/em>, and in 1959 he was chosen by <a href=\"http://www.biography.com/people/kirk-douglas-9278036\">Kirk Douglas<\/a> to author the screenplay for <em>Spartacus<\/em>. Trumbo’s authorship of these two highly successful pictures was revealed shortly before their release in 1960, along with the announcement that Trumbo would receive credit for his work. Shortly thereafter he was readmitted to the Writers Guild of America, effectively bringing the blacklist to an end.&nbsp;<\/p><h2>Back in the Fold&nbsp;<\/h2><p>Trumbo returned to work in earnest and for the remainder of his life continued his prolific and successful output. Of the many screenplays that he wrote during this post-blacklist era, some highlights are the Kirk Douglas western <em>Lonely Are the Brave <\/em>(1962), the Golden Globe–nominated crime drama <em>The Fixer<\/em> (1968) and the 1973 prison classic <em>Papillon<\/em>, starring <a href=\"http://www.biography.com/people/steve-mcqueen-9394602\">Steve McQueen<\/a> and <a href=\"http://www.biography.com/people/dustin-hoffman-9341124\">Dustin Hoffman<\/a>. Revisiting the work that was at the root of so much of his past troubles, Trumbo wrote and directed a 1971 film adaption of <em>Johnny Got His Gun<\/em>, for which he received two awards at the Cannes Film Festival. Several years later he was finally delivered his Oscar for <em>The Brave One.&nbsp;<\/em><\/p><p>A heavy smoker for much of his life, in 1973 Trumbo was diagnosed with lung cancer. He died of a heart attack while in hospice care several years later, on September 10, 1976, in Los Angeles, California, and donated his body to science. In 1993, 40 years after the film’s release, Trumbo was posthumously awarded an Oscar for his screenplay for <em>Roman Holiday<\/em>.<\/p><h2>Trumbo Redux&nbsp;<\/h2><p>Since his death, Dalton Trumbo has been the subject of a&nbsp;variety of different works, including a 2003 Broadway play called <em>Trumbo: Red, White and Blacklisted<\/em> and a related 2009 documentary. In September 2015, a new biographical drama titled <em>Trumbo<\/em> premiered at the Toronto International Film Festival. Starring <a href=\"http://www.biography.com/people/bryan-cranston-21347665\">Bryan Cranston<\/a> as Trumbo, and with a cast that includes <a href=\"http://www.biography.com/people/helen-mirren-547434\">Helen Mirren<\/a>, <a href=\"http://www.biography.com/people/john-goodman-476702\">John Goodman<\/a>, <a href=\"http://www.biography.com/people/diane-lane-9542310\">Diane Lane<\/a> and <a href=\"http://www.biography.com/people/louis-ck-21014255\">Louis C.K.<\/a>, the film is scheduled for a November 2015 domestic release.<\/p><div tml-external-provider=\"youtube\" tml-external-id=\"n0dZ_2ICpJE\" tml-embed-src=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=n0dZ_2ICpJE\" tml-render-layout=\"inline\" Hollywood was a major focus of the accusations, and after 10 actors refused to testify in front of the House Committee on Un-American Activities, the blacklist was created. Hundreds of actors, actresses, directors, screenwriters and other entertainment professionals were barred from working. Here are some of the famous people who were on the Hollywood blacklist.<\/p><p><\/p>\n","slug":"blacklisted","displayName":"Blacklisted","primaryContentSiteId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e","teaser":"In the 1940s and 1950s, the United States was in the grips of a \"red scare.","promoTitle":"Blacklisted","dek":"In the 1940s and 1950s, the United States was in the grips of a \"red scare.","primarySiteId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e","statusCode":"complete"},{"publicationTimestamp":"2014-04-02T03:08:34Z","createdPrincipalId":"up016bb0b82173860f","commentsEnabled":true,"metaDescription":"Explore Biography's collection of famous people who changed their names. tml-embed-src=\"https://players.brightcove.net/4495439099001/rkC8QsjOx_default/index.html?playlistId=5336222410001&autoplay=true\"><\/div>\n        \n<p>From the early days of film, directors have \n\n","slug":"famous-alumni-of-university-of-oxford","displayName":"University of Oxford","primaryContentSiteId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e","promoTitle":"Famous University of Oxford of Melbourne","authoringStatusCode":"in_progress","primaryImage":{"createdPrincipalId":"up016bb0b82173860f","height":402,"cloudinaryVersionId":1396417826,"id":"ci01a33b79f5ea860e","objectType":"ContentPhoto","title":"Peter-Singer-39994-1-402","primaryPhotoId":"ci01a33b79f5ea860e","hasFaces":true,"width":402,"publicId":"MTE4MDAzNDEwMjQ0NTAzMDU0","format":"jpg","createdTimestamp":"2014-04-02T05:50:28Z","primaryContentSiteId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e","bytes":186112,"primarySiteId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e"},"vocabularyId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e:schools","editedByPrincipalId":"up016bb0b82173860f","editedTimestamp":"2014-04-02T05:50:32Z","disqusId":"b3c99564-ba2a-11e3-83c8-002219604f34","originalPublicationTimestamp":"2014-04-02T05:47:32Z","createdTimestamp":"2014-04-02T05:50:32Z","versionId":"1","primaryImageId":"ci01a33b79f5ea860e","path":"/people/groups/famous-alumni-of-university-of-melbourne","isWorkInProgress":false,"slug":"famous-alumni-of-university-of-melbourne","displayName":"University of Melbourne","primaryContentSiteId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e","promoTitle":"Famous University of Melbourne Alumni","primarySiteId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e","statusCode":"complete"}],"deathYearCe":true,"gender":"Male","birthCirca":false,"birthMonth":"7","metaDescription":"Read about philosopher and activist Peter Singer. Learn about his early life and later, controversial career, at Biography.com. ","editedTimestamp":"2015-09-25T14:36:53Z","authoringStatusCode":"in_progress","profileTml":"<!-- tml-version=\"2\" --><section tml-anchor=\"synopsis\"><h2>Synopsis<\/h2><p>Born in Melbourne, Australia, in 1946, Peter Singer attended the University of Melbourne, where he earned both a B.A. and an M.A. in philosophy. In 1969 he enrolled at the University of Oxford, receiving his B.Phil. degree from the school two years later. Over the course of his long career, Singer has become one of the leading bioethicists and one of the founders of the animal rights movement.<\/p><\/section><section tml-anchor=\"early-years\"><h2>Early Years<\/h2><p>Hailed for his work in bioethics and one of the key founders of the animal rights movement, Peter Albert David Singer has been called the most controversial and influential philosopher alive today.<\/p><p>Born July 6, 1946, in Melbourne, Australia, Singer is the son of Jewish parents who escaped Nazi-ruled Vienna in 1938. Singer grew up in Melbourne, where he eventually attended the University of Melbourne, from which he earned his B.A. and M.A. in philosophy in 1967 and 1969, respectively.<\/p><p>Following his graduation from his home city university, Singer enrolled at the University of Oxford, earning his B. Phil. degree from the school in 1971. Singer remained at Oxford the next two years, working as a Radcliffe Lecturer in Philosophy at University College.<\/p><p>Singer's time in England proved instrumental. There, he became committed to vegetarianism. His affiliation with the cause led to his controversial and well-known publication <em>Animal Liberation: A New Ethics for Our Treatment of Animals<\/em> in 1975.<\/p><p>The work's publication articulated a careful argument that gave moral standing to animals. It also drew greater awareness to abuses at factory farms and scientific research, while also helping to lay the groundwork for other debates around stem-cell research and third-trimester abortions.<\/p><p>In addition, it pointed Singer on a path of activism that has touched a range of causes, from environmentalism and women's rights, to anti-war causes and civil rights.<\/p><\/section><section tml-anchor=\"controversial-figure\"><h2>Controversial Figure<\/h2><p>Singer's willingness to wade deep into controversial topics has made him a lightning rod for groups around the world. Driving much of his work is his own embrace of utilitarianism, an ethical philosophy that holds that the best actions are those that maximize happiness and reduce suffering.<\/p><p>Throughout his long career, Singer has been a strong proponent of eliminating poverty, arguing that anyone who has more than they need should be giving to those in need.<\/p><p>In what some consider his most controversial work, <em>Practical Ethics<\/em> (1979), Singer looked closely at why and how a living being's interests should be valued. The work tackled a number of hot-button topics as Singer evaluated the philosophical and ethical underpinnings behind sex discrimination, animal welfare, foreign aid and abortion.<\/p><p>Among pro-life activists in particular, Singer has proven to be a popular target. His belief that newborns should not be considered a person until 30 days after their birth, and his allowance that physicians should have the right to kill some disabled babies, has drawn condemnation from anti-abortion leaders from around the world.<\/p><\/section><section tml-anchor=\"princeton-appointment\"><h2>Princeton Appointment<\/h2><p>In 1999, Princeton University came under heavy fire for its appointment of Singer as the DeCamp Professor at the Center for Human Values.<\/p><p>Princeton's president, Harold Shapiro, stood his ground and quickly defended the decision. \"His books, including Animal Liberation and Practical Ethics, have been translated into 15 languages and have been widely taught in ethics classes throughout Europe and the United States, including here at Princeton,\" wrote Shapiro. \"He is a gifted teacher, whose clarity and originality have made ethical issues come alive to a broad intellectual audience.\"<\/p><p>With all the controversy, however, has come praise. In 2004 Singer was honored as the Australian Humanist of the Year. Not long after, <em>Time<\/em> magazine named Singer to its list of the world's 100 most influential people. In June 2012, Singer was also named a Companion of the Order of Australia for his work in philosophy and bioethics.<\/p><\/section>","primaryImage":{"createdPrincipalId":"up016bb0b82173860f","height":402,"cloudinaryVersionId":1396417826,"id":"ci01a33b79f5ea860e","objectType":"ContentPhoto","title":"Peter-Singer-39994-1-402","primaryPhotoId":"ci01a33b79f5ea860e","hasFaces":true,"width":402,"publicId":"MTE4MDAzNDEwMjQ0NTAzMDU0","format":"jpg","createdTimestamp":"2014-04-02T05:50:28Z","primaryContentSiteId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e","bytes":186112,"primarySiteId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e"},"birthCountry":{"publicationTimestamp":"2014-04-02T04:37:50Z","createdPrincipalId":"up016bb0b82173860f","commentsEnabled":true,"id":"ci01a87e1d5671860f","objectType":"ContentRichTerm","isNoindex":false,"title":"Australia","authoringStatusCode":"in_progress","primaryImage":{"createdPrincipalId":"up016bb0b82173860f","height":402,"cloudinaryVersionId":1396413643,"id":"ci01ac7ce9c159860c","objectType":"ContentPhoto","title":"J-Robin-Warren-37267-1-402","primaryPhotoId":"ci01ac7ce9c159860c","hasFaces":true,"width":402,"publicId":"MTE5NTU2MzE1ODYwOTI4MDEx","format":"jpg","createdTimestamp":"2014-04-02T04:40:44Z","primaryContentSiteId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e","bytes":64967,"primarySiteId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e"},"vocabularyId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e:birth_country","editedByPrincipalId":"up016bb0b82173860f","editedTimestamp":"2014-04-02T04:40:48Z","disqusId":"f5df8c74-ba20-11e3-a9ad-002219604f34","originalPublicationTimestamp":"2014-04-02T04:37:50Z","createdTimestamp":"2014-04-02T04:40:48Z","versionId":"1","primaryImageId":"ci01ac7ce9c159860c","path":"/people/groups/born-in-australia","isWorkInProgress":false,"slug":"born-in-australia","displayName":"Australia","primaryContentSiteId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e","promoTitle":"Famous States","primaryContentSiteId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e","promoTitle":"Famous People Who Died in United States","primarySiteId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e","statusCode":"complete"},"birthCirca":false,"birthMonth":"6","metaDescription":"A fierce opponent to corporate power, politician Robert M. La Follette ruffled more than a few feathers in his time. More at Biography.com.","editedTimestamp":"2015-01-22T21:02:30Z","deathState":{"publicationTimestamp":"2014-04-02T04:22:54Z","createdPrincipalId":"up016bb0b82173860f","commentsEnabled":true,"id":"ci01a33b79f086860e","objectType":"ContentRichTerm","isNoindex":false,"title":"D.C.","authoringStatusCode":"in_progress","primaryImage":{"createdPrincipalId":"up016bb0b82173860f","height":402,"cloudinaryVersionId":1396412747,"id":"ci01a33b79f084860e","objectType":"ContentPhoto","title":"Charlotte-Forten-11384-1-402","primaryPhotoId":"ci01a33b79f084860e","hasFaces":true,"width":402,"publicId":"MTE5NTU2MzE1ODQ5Nzg2ODkx","format":"jpg","createdTimestamp":"2014-04-02T04:25:48Z","primaryContentSiteId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e","bytes":50301,"primarySiteId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e"},"vocabularyId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e:death_state","editedByPrincipalId":"up016bb0b82173860f","editedTimestamp":"2014-04-02T04:25:51Z","disqusId":"df5d0938-ba1e-11e3-a03d-002219604f34","originalPublicationTimestamp":"2014-04-02T04:22:54Z","createdTimestamp":"2014-04-02T04:25:51Z","versionId":"1","primaryImageId":"ci01a33b79f084860e","path":"/people/groups/died-in-dc","isWorkInProgress":false,"slug":"died-in-dc","displayName":"D.C.","primaryContentSiteId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e","promoTitle":"Famous People Who Died in D.C.","primarySiteId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e","statusCode":"complete"},"authoringStatusCode":"in_progress","profileTml":"<!-- tml-version=\"2\" --><section tml-anchor=\"synopsis\"><h2>Synopsis<\/h2><p>Robert M. La Follette was an American Republican and politician who is best known as a proponent of progressivism and a fierce opponent to corporate power. He served as a member of the U.S. House of Representatives, the Governor of Wisconsin and a U.S. Senator from Wisconsin during his career. He also ran for President of the United States in 1924.<\/p><h2>Early Life<\/h2><p>“Fighting Bob La Follette” was born Robert Marion La Follette in Dane County, Wisconsin, on June 14, 1855. He worked as a farm laborer before entering the University of Wisconsin in 1875. Graduating four years later, La Follette was admitted to the Wisconsin bar in 1880. He married his college sweetheart, Belle Case, on December 31, 1881.<\/p><p>Robert La Follette launched his political career as Dane County District Attorney in 1881 in spite of objections from Republican bosses who felt his ideas were too progressive.  In 1884, he was elected to Congress, but generally voted the “Party Line” on most issues. In 1890, he was defeated in the Democrat election landslide and returned to Madison, Wisconsin to practice law. <\/p><h2>Declaration of War against Political Corruption<\/h2><p>His hiatus from politics didn’t last long. In 1891, U.S. Senator Philetus Sawyer, the state’s Republican leader, offered La Follette a bribe to fix a court case. La Follette was furious and declared war on the party machine denouncing the use of money to reverse the will of the people.  For the next ten years, La Follette traveled the state speaking out against the influence of powerful business interests and the corrupt politicians. Though he lost elections for governor in 1896 and 1898, he became a political celebrity with this outgoing personality and extraordinary flair for zealous oratory. <\/p><p>Finally, in 1900, Robert La Follette was elected governor of Wisconsin. In his first two terms he pushed several Progressive initiatives, but nearly all were blocked by the state legislature. Instituting a system later known as the “Wisconsin Idea”, he commissioned leading political science academics to help create a “laboratory of democracy” drafting bills and administering state agencies. Another effective tool he used was publically reading the “roll call” of votes state legislators to show citizen how their representatives were voting on key issues. The threat of exposing legislators’ votes for special interests helped and get many of La Follette’s reforms passed. <\/p><h2>Crusading U.S. Senator <\/h2><p>In 1906, Robert La Follette resigned as governor and was elected to the U.S. Senate. La Follette won instant fame as a Senator not controlled by special interests. Over the next eight years he pushed for dismantling the business trusts, supporting environmental protection, protecting labor unions right to strike, and the 17 Amendment allowing for direct election of U.S. Senators. In 1909, he and his wife Belle founded La Follette’s Weekly magazine (later called The Progressive) which campaigned for woman’s suffrage, racial equality, and other progressive causes. <\/p><p>Seriously considered a presidential candidate in 1912, Robert La Follette was passed over by the Republican Party when Theodore Roosevelt entered the race. Bitterly disappointed, La Follette supported Woodrow Wilson’s election and his early neutrality policies. He adamantly opposed America’s entry into World War I. After the war, he campaigned against the Treaty of Versailles and U.S. membership in the League of Nations. Critics declared his war opposition political suicide, but he was reelected to the Senate in 1922.<\/p><h2>Final Act<\/h2><p>  Convinced the war had given big business too much influence in government, Robert La Follette began exposing flagrant corruption. Between 1921 and 1924 he played a prominent role in exposing the Tea Pot Dome scandals. With the support of farm groups, labor organizations and the Socialist Party, Robert La Follette ran for president in 1924, but lost to Calvin Coolidge. The experiences exhausted him both physically and spiritually.  He died the following year on June 18, 1925 of cardiovascular disease. After his death, his wife, Belle, and two sons, Robert Jr. and Philip carried on his legacy. Both sons entered politics as Progressives with Philip playing a prominent role in Wisconsin politics as governor and Robert, Jr. taking his father’s seat in the US Senate.&nbsp;<\/p><\/section><div Alumni","primarySiteId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e","statusCode":"complete"},{"publicationTimestamp":"2014-04-02T07:56:38Z","createdPrincipalId":"up016bb0b82173860f","commentsEnabled":true,"id":"ci01a8bfd606db860b","objectType":"ContentRichTerm","isNoindex":false,"title":"Bank Street College","authoringStatusCode":"in_progress","primaryImage":{"createdPrincipalId":"up016bb0b82173860f","height":402,"cloudinaryVersionId":1396425575,"id":"ci01a87e1d6426860f","objectType":"ContentPhoto","title":"Bill-Ayers-380916-1-402","primaryPhotoId":"ci01a87e1d6426860f","hasFaces":true,"width":402,"publicId":"MTE5NTU2MzE2MDg0MTQzNjI3","format":"jpg","createdTimestamp":"2014-04-02T07:59:36Z","primaryContentSiteId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e","bytes":78278,"primarySiteId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e"},"vocabularyId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e:schools","editedByPrincipalId":"up016bb0b82173860f","editedTimestamp":"2014-04-02T07:59:41Z","disqusId":"be5bedda-ba3c-11e3-80a4-002219604f34","originalPublicationTimestamp":"2014-04-02T07:56:38Z","createdTimestamp":"2014-04-02T07:59:41Z","versionId":"1","primaryImageId":"ci01a87e1d6426860f","path":"/people/groups/famous-alumni-of-bank-street-college","isWorkInProgress":false,"slug":"famous-alumni-of-bank-street-college","displayName":"Bank Alumni","primarySiteId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e","statusCode":"complete"}],"deathYearCe":true,"gender":"Male","birthCirca":false,"birthMonth":"12","metaDescription":"Visit Biography.com to learn more about Bill Ayers, a founder of the Weather Underground, a militant anti-war group of the 1960's and 1970's. ","editedTimestamp":"2014-09-29T14:24:03Z","authoringStatusCode":"in_progress","profileTml":"<!-- tml-version=\"2\" --><section tml-anchor=\"synopsis\"><h2>Synopsis<\/h2><p>Bill Ayers, educator and activist, was born in Oak Park, Illinois. During his undergraduate studies at the University of Michigan, Ayers became involved with the Students for a Democratic Society(SDS) and the movement to end the war in Vietnam. He and several others founded the Weather Underground, believing the anti-war movement needed to use violence, if necessary, to achieve its goals.  <\/p><\/section><section tml-anchor=\"early-life\"><h2>Early Life<\/h2><p>Activist, educator, author, member of the Weathermen (later known as  the Weather Underground). Born William Charles Ayers on December 26,  1944, in Oak Park, Illinois. A former radical activist, Bill Ayers has  established himself as an educator and author. He grew up as the middle  child of five in the Chicago suburb of Glen Ellyn. His father was a  business executive and his mother was a homemaker.<\/p><p>As a high  school junior, Ayers was sent to Lake Forest Academy, a prep school  north of Chicago. He joined his older brother Tim to University of  Michigan in Ann Arbor after graduating from the academy. At the  university, Ayers became politically active, joining the Students for a  Democratic Society (SDS), which sought social and political change and  opposed U.S. involvement in Vietnam. He took a break from college to  work at an experimental private school in Ann Arbor in 1965 and then  moved to Cleveland, Ohio, to help with a new school there. Returning to  the university, Ayers continued to be involved in political and social  causes, especially the anti-war movement. He graduated in 1968 with a  bachelor’s degree in American studies.<\/p><\/section><section tml-anchor=\"the-weathermen\"><h2>The Weathermen<\/h2><p>After college, Ayers  devoted much of his time to his activism. He was among the demonstrators  at the 1968 Democratic National Convention. Developing a more militant  version of the SDS, Ayers helped found the Weathermen the following  year. The group thought more drastic measures were needed to end the war  in Vietnam. In October 1969, the Weathermen took to the streets in what  was called the “Days of Rage” protests. The event started off with the  bombing of a statue in Chicago’s Haymarket Square and then erupted into a  clash between the group members and the police. During the conflict,  287 Weathermen were arrested. <\/p> <p>Later that year, the group took  responsibility for bombing several police cars in Chicago in retaliation  for the killing of Mark Clark and Fred Hampton of the Black Panther  Party by the police. By early 1970, many members of the group were in  hiding, including Ayers. The organization was rocked by tragedy in March  of that year when three members—Theodore Gold, Terry Robbins, and  Ayers’ girlfriend Diana Oughton—were killed while making bombs in New  York City.<\/p> <p>Even after these deaths, the group remained active.  Ayers participated in the 1971 bombing of the Capitol building and the  1972 bombing of the Pentagon, according to his 2001 book <em>Fugitive Days: A Memoir<\/em>.  He remained underground for a decade. While on the run, Ayers became  involved with fellow Weather Underground member Bernardine Dorhn. The  two decided to come out of hiding in 1980 after the birth of their  second child together, a son named Malik. (Their older son Zayd was born  in 1977.)<\/p> <p>Federal charges against Ayers and Dohrn were dismissed because of “improper surveillance,” according to an article in the <em>Chicago Sun-Times<\/em>.  Ayers returned to school to study early childhood education at Bank  Street College of Education and received his master’s degree in 1984.  Staying on there, he worked as an instructor while working on a  doctorate in curriculum and teaching, which he completed in 1987. Ayers  joined the faculty of the University of Illinois at Chicago in 1992. In  addition to his work at the university, he has become an accomplished  author, writing numerous works on education, including <em>The Good Preschool Teacher: Six Teachers Reflect on Their Lives<\/em> (1989), <em>To Teach: The Journey of a Teacher<\/em> (1993), and <em>Teaching for Social Justice: A Democracy and Education Reader<\/em> (1998).   <\/p><\/section><section tml-anchor=\"media-attention-during-the-2008-elections\"><h2>Media Attention During the 2008 Elections<\/h2><p>During the 2008 presidential campaign, Ayers found  himself in the midst of media maelstrom. His connection to Democratic  candidate Barack Obama became an issue brought up by John McCain’s  campaign, which made automated calls to voters in several states,  including Nevada and Wisconsin. The message, in part, said that Obama  “has worked closely with domestic terrorist Bill Ayers, whose  organization bombed the U.S. Capitol, the Pentagon, a judge’s home and  killed Americans,” according to an Associated Press report.<\/p> <p>Obama  and Ayers have known each other for years. Ayers and Dohrn hosted an  event for Obama at their house in the mid-1990s during Obama’s first  campaign for the Illinois Senate. They both have worked with two  non-profit groups, the Woods Fund of Chicago and Chicago Anneberg  Challenge, over the years. They have not been in contact with each  other, however, since 2005 excluding one chance encounter in their  shared neighborhood in 2007, according to a report in <em>The New York Times<\/em>.  \"The suggestion that Ayers was a political adviser to Obama or someone  who shaped his political views is patently false,\" said Obama campaign  spokesperson Ben LaBolt to <em>The New York Times<\/em>.     <\/p> <p>Ayers,  a professor at the University of Illinois at Chicago, is on sabbatical  for the 2008-2009 academic year. He lives in Chicago’s Hyde Park  neighborhood with Bernardine Dohrn.<\/p> <\/section>","birthCountry":{"publicationTimestamp":"2014-04-02T04:18:20Z","createdPrincipalId":"up016bb0b82173860f","commentsEnabled":true,"id":"ci01a33b79f056860e","objectType":"ContentRichTerm","isNoindex":false,"title":"United States","authoringStatusCode":"in_progress","primaryImage":{"createdPrincipalId":"up016bb0b82173860f","height":402,"cloudinaryVersionId":1396412473,"id":"ci019b6c01fe65860d","objectType":"ContentPhoto","title":"William-Atherton-4822-1-402","primaryPhotoId":"ci019b6c01fe65860d","hasFaces":true,"width":402,"publicId":"MTE1ODA0OTcxMjQ2ODQ3NTAx","format":"jpg","createdTimestamp":"2014-04-02T04:21:14Z","primaryContentSiteId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e","bytes":76197,"primarySiteId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e"},"vocabularyId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e:birth_country","editedByPrincipalId":"up016bb0b82173860f","editedTimestamp":"2014-04-02T04:21:17Z","disqusId":"3c2c2230-ba1e-11e3-9706-002219604f34","originalPublicationTimestamp":"2014-04-02T04:18:20Z","createdTimestamp":"2014-04-02T04:21:17Z","versionId":"1","primaryImageId":"ci019b6c01fe65860d","path":"/people/groups/born-in-united-states","isWorkInProgress":false,"slug":"born-in-united-states","displayName":"United States","primaryContentSiteId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e","promoTitle":"Famous People Born in United States","primarySiteId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e","statusCode":"complete"},"bestKnownFor":"Bill Ayers is best known for his involvement with the Weather Underground, a militant group created to end the Vietnam War. People Who Died in Germany","primarySiteId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e","statusCode":"complete"},"birthCirca":false,"birthMonth":"4","metaDescription":"Max Weber was an unwitting founder of modern sociology. Explore his life and work, including <i>The Protestant Ethic and The Spirit of Capitalism<\/i>, at Biography.com.","editedTimestamp":"2014-09-15T19:04:27Z","authoringStatusCode":"in_progress","profileTml":"<!-- tml-version=\"2\" --><section tml-anchor=\"synopsis\"><h2>Synopsis<\/h2><p>Born in Germany in 1864, Max Weber was a precocious child. He went to university and became a professor, but suffered a mental breakdown in 1897 that left him unable to work for five years. In 1905 he published his most famous work, <em>The Protestant Ethic and the Spirit of Capitalism<\/em>. He returned to teaching in 1918 and died in 1920. He is considered the father of modern sociology.<\/p><\/section><section tml-anchor=\"early-life-and-education\"><h2>Early Life and Education<\/h2><p>Max Weber was born on April 21, 1864. His father, Max Weber Sr., was a politically active lawyer with a penchant for “earthly pleasures,” while his mother, Helene Fallenstein Weber, preferred a more ascetic lifestyle. The conflicts this created in their marriage acutely influenced Max. Still, their house was full of prominent intellectuals and lively discourse, an environment in which Weber thrived. Growing up, he was bored with school and disdained his teachers, but devoured classic literature on his own.<\/p> <p>After graduating from high school, Weber studied law, history, philosophy and economics for three semesters at Heidelberg University before spending a year in the military. When he resumed his studies in 1884, he went to the University of Berlin and spent one semester at Göttingen. He passed the bar exam in 1886 and earned his Ph.D. in 1889, ultimately completing his habitation thesis, which allowed him to obtain a position in academia.<\/p><\/section><section tml-anchor=\"early-career\"><h2>Early Career<\/h2><p>Weber married a distant cousin, Marianne Schnitger, in 1893. He got a job teaching economics at Freiburg University the following year, before returning to Heidelberg in 1896 as a professor. In 1897, Max had a falling out with his father, which went unresolved. After his father died in 1897, Weber suffered a mental breakdown. He was plagued by depression, anxiety and insomnia, which made it impossible for him to teach. He spent the next five years in and out of sanatoriums.<\/p> <p>When Weber was finally able to resume working in 1903, he became an editor at a prominent social science journal. In 1904, he was invited to deliver a lecture at the Congress of Arts and Sciences in St. Louis, Missouri and later became widely known for his famed essays, <em>The Protestant Ethic and the Spirit of Capitalism<\/em>. These essays, published in 1904 and 1905, discussed his idea that the rise of modern capitalism was attributable to Protestantism, particularly Calvinism.<\/p><\/section><section tml-anchor=\"later-work\"><h2>Later Work<\/h2><p>After a stint volunteering in the medical service during World War I, Weber published three more books on religion in a sociological context. These works, <em>The Religion of China<\/em> (1916), <em>The Religion of India<\/em> (1916) and <em>Ancient Judaism<\/em> (1917-1918), contrasted their respective religions and cultures with that of the Western world by weighing the importance of economic and religious factors, among others, on historical outcomes. Weber resumed teaching in 1918. He intended to publish additional volumes on Christianity and Islam, but he contracted the Spanish flu and died in Munich on June 14, 1920. His manuscript of <em>Economy and Society<\/em> was left unfinished; it was edited by his wife and published in 1922.<\/p><\/section><section tml-anchor=\"legacy\"><h2>Legacy<\/h2><p>Weber's writing helped form the basis of modern sociology. His influence runs throughout the realms of sociology, politics, religion and economics.<\/p><\/section>","primaryImage":{"createdPrincipalId":"up016bb0b82173860f","height":402,"cloudinaryVersionId":1396459146,"id":"ci01a8bfd619d4860b","objectType":"ContentPhoto","title":"Max-Weber-9526066-1-402","primaryPhotoId":"ci01a8bfd619d4860b","hasFaces":true,"width":402,"publicId":"MTE5NDg0MDU1MTYzOTMwMTI3","format":"jpg","createdTimestamp":"2014-04-02T17:19:08Z","primaryContentSiteId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e","bytes":68655,"primarySiteId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e"},"birthCountry":{"publicationTimestamp":"2014-04-02T04:25:54Z","createdPrincipalId":"up016bb0b82173860f","commentsEnabled":true,"id":"ci01a33b79f0a5860e","objectType":"ContentRichTerm","isNoindex":false,"title":"Germany","authoringStatusCode":"in_progress","primaryImage":{"createdPrincipalId":"up016bb0b82173860f","height":402,"cloudinaryVersionId":1396404519,"id":"ci01a87e1d4fa6860f","objectType":"ContentPhoto","title":"Claudia-Schiffer-24938-1-402","primaryPhotoId":"ci01a87e1d4fa6860f","hasFaces":true,"width":402,"publicId":"MTIwNjA4NjMzMzQ5MjQ0NDI4","format":"jpg","createdTimestamp":"2014-04-02T02:08:40Z","primaryContentSiteId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e","bytes":123974,"primarySiteId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e"},"vocabularyId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e:birth_country","editedByPrincipalId":"up016bb0b82173860f","editedTimestamp":"2014-04-02T04:28:51Z","disqusId":"4a70f086-ba1f-11e3-9b5d-002219604f34","originalPublicationTimestamp":"2014-04-02T04:25:54Z","createdTimestamp":"2014-04-02T04:28:51Z","versionId":"1","primaryImageId":"ci01a87e1d4fa6860f","path":"/people/groups/born-in-germany","isWorkInProgress":false,"slug":"born-in-germany","displayName":"Germany","primaryContentSiteId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e","promoTitle":"Famous People Born in Germany","primarySiteId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e","statusCode":"complete"},"bestKnownFor":"Max Weber was a 19th-century German sociologist and one of the founders of modern sociology. He was a free-thinker who later worked as a teacher, social worker and union organizer. Baldwin was a conscientious objector during WWI and co-established the American Civil Liberties Union in 1920, helming the well-known organization for decades. He died on August 26, \n\n","slug":"famous-alumni-of-harvard-university","displayName":"Harvard University","primaryContentSiteId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e","promoTitle":"Famous Harvard University Alumni","primarySiteId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e","statusCode":"complete"},{"publicationTimestamp":"2014-04-02T07:07:27Z","createdPrincipalId":"up016bb0b82173860f","commentsEnabled":true,"id":"ci01ac7ce9caeb860c","objectType":"ContentRichTerm","isNoindex":false,"title":"Cranbrook School","authoringStatusCode":"in_progress","primaryImage":{"createdPrincipalId":"up016bb0b82173860f","height":402,"cloudinaryVersionId":1396422623,"id":"ci01a33b79fae5860e","objectType":"ContentPhoto","title":"Mitt-Romney-241055-1-402","primaryPhotoId":"ci01a33b79fae5860e","hasFaces":true,"width":402,"publicId":"MTE1ODA0OTcxNDMwNDc5Mzcz","format":"jpg","createdTimestamp":"2014-04-02T07:10:25Z","primaryContentSiteId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e","bytes":53700,"primarySiteId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e"},"vocabularyId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e:schools","editedByPrincipalId":"up016bb0b82173860f","editedTimestamp":"2014-04-02T07:10:29Z","disqusId":"df0b4e2e-ba35-11e3-a592-002219604f34","originalPublicationTimestamp":"2014-04-02T07:07:27Z","createdTimestamp":"2014-04-02T07:10:29Z","versionId":"1","primaryImageId":"ci01a33b79fae5860e","path":"/people/groups/famous-alumni-of-cranbrook-school","isWorkInProgress":false,"slug":"famous-alumni-of-cranbrook-school","displayName":"Cranbrook School","primaryContentSiteId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e","promoTitle":"Famous Cranbrook School Alumni","primarySiteId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e","statusCode":"complete"}],"deathYearCe":true,"gender":"Male","birthCirca":false,"birthMonth":"4","metaDescription":"Daniel Ellsberg is known for leaking the Pentagon Papers to the press and opposing the Vietnam War. Learn more at Biography.com.","editedTimestamp":"2014-04-02T20:52:50Z","authoringStatusCode":"in_progress","profileTml":"<!-- tml-version=\"2\" --><section tml-anchor=\"synopsis\"><h2>Synopsis<\/h2><p>Born in Chicago in 1931, military strategist Daniel Ellsberg helped strengthen public opposition to the Vietnam War in 1971 by leaking secret documents known as the Pentagon Papers to the <em>New York Times<\/em>. The documents contained evidence that the U.S. government had misled the public regarding U.S. involvement in the war.<\/p><\/section><section tml-anchor=\"early-life\"><h2>Early Life<\/h2><p>Military analyst Daniel Ellsberg was born on April 7, 1931, in Chicago, Illinois, and grew up in Highland Park, Michigan. His father, Harry Ellsberg, worked as a civil engineer and his mother, Adele, worked as a fundraiser at the National Jewish Hospital but quit working upon her marriage. Both of Ellsberg's parents were Jewish by heritage but fervent converts to Christian Science. Neighbors and classmates remember young Daniel Ellsberg as an introverted and unusual child.<\/p> <p>\"Danny was just never one of the guys,\" one classmate recalled. \"He wasn't like the rest of the boys.\" Another neighbor recalled: \"I don't think we walked to school with him ever. He never fraternized with any of the young people in the neighborhood.\" However, Ellsberg was also an extraordinarily gifted child, excelling especially at math and piano. He read constantly and possessed phenomenal recall, once appearing on a Detroit radio station to recite the entire Gettysburg Address from memory.<\/p> <p>Ellsberg received a full academic scholarship to attend the prestigious Cranbrook School in Bloomfield Hills, just outside Detroit, Michigan, ultimately graduating first in his class in 1948 and thus earning another full academic scholarship to study at Harvard. There he majored in economics and wrote a senior honors thesis entitled \"Theories of Decision-making Under Uncertainty: The Contributions of von Neumann and Morgenstern,\" which he later developed into journal articles published in the <em>Economic Journal<\/em> and <em>American Economics Review<\/em>.<\/p> <p>Upon graduating from Harvard summa cum laude in 1952, Ellsberg received a Woodrow Wilson Scholarship to study economics for a year at King's College, Cambridge University. He returned to the United States in 1953 and immediately volunteered to serve in the Marine Corps Officer Candidates Program (he had earlier been granted educational deferments of military service). Ellsberg served in the Marine Corps for three years, from 1954-'57, working as rifle platoon leader, operations officer and rifle company commander. He extended his service for six months to serve in the U.S. 6th Fleet in the Mediterranean during the 1956 Suez Crisis in Egypt.<\/p> <p>After completing his military service, Ellsberg returned to Harvard on a three-year Junior Fellowship with the Society of Fellows to pursue independent graduate study in economics. In 1959, he landed a position as strategic analyst at the RAND Corporation, a highly influential nonprofit that closely advised the U.S. government on military strategy. After first working as a consultant to the Commander-in-Chief Pacific, in 1961 he was assigned to draft the Secretary of Defense Guidance to the Joint Chiefs of Staff on operational plans in the event of a nuclear war.<\/p> <p>When the Cuban Missile Crisis unfolded a year later, Ellsberg was immediately summoned to Washington, D.C. to serve on the various working groups reporting to the Executive Committee of the National Security Council. That same year he completed his Ph.D. in economics at Harvard with a thesis titled \"Risk, Ambiguity and Decision.\" He published an article presenting his findings in the Quarterly Journal of Economics that popularized the concept now dubbed the \"Ellsberg Paradox,\" exploring situations in which people's choices violate the expected utility hypothesis.<\/p><\/section> <section tml-anchor=\"government-service-and-pentagon-papers\"><h2>Government Service and Pentagon Papers<\/h2><p>In 1964, Ellsberg went to work for the Department of Defense as a  Special Assistant to Assistant Secretary of Defense for International  Security Affairs John T. McNaughton. In a fateful coincidence, his first  day of work at the Pentagon, August 4, 1964, was the day of the alleged  second attack (which in fact did not occur) on the USS Maddox in the  Tonkin Gulf off the coast of Vietnam&mdash;an incident that provided much of  the public justification for full-scale American intervention in the  Vietnam War.<\/p> <p>Ellsberg's primary responsibility for the Defense  Department was to craft secret plans to escalate the war in Vietnam&mdash;plans he says he personally regarded as \"wrongheaded and dangerous\" and  hoped would never be carried out. Nevertheless, when President Lyndon  Johnson chose to ramp up American involvement in the conflict in 1965,  Ellsberg moved to Vietnam to work out of the American Embassy in Saigon  evaluating pacification efforts along the front lines. He eventually  left Vietnam in June 1967 after contracting hepatitis.<\/p> <p>Returning to the RAND Corporation later that year, Ellsberg worked on a  top-secret report ordered by Defense Secretary Robert McNamara entitled  U.S. Decision-making in Vietnam, 1945-1968. Better known as \"The  Pentagon Papers,\" the final product was a 7,000-page, 47-volume study  that Ellsberg called \"evidence of a quarter century of aggression,  broken treaties, deceptions, stolen elections, lies and murder.\"  Although he worked as a consultant on Vietnam policy to new President  Richard Nixon and Secretary of State Henry Kissinger throughout 1969,  Ellsberg grew increasingly frustrated with their insistence on expanding  upon previous administrations' policies of escalation and deception in  Vietnam.<\/p> <p>Inspired by a young Harvard graduate named Randy Kehler who  worked with the War Resisters League and was imprisoned for refusing to  cooperate with the military draft&mdash;as well as by reading Thoreau,  Gandhi and Dr. Martin Luther King&mdash;Ellsberg decided to end what he saw  as his complicity with the Vietnam War and start working to bring about  its end. He recalled, \"Their example put the question in my head: What  could I do to help shorten this war, now that I'm prepared to go to  prison for it?\"<\/p> <p>In late 1969, with the help of former RAND colleague Anthony Russo, Ellsberg began secretly photocopying the entire Pentagon Papers. He privately offered the Papers to several congressmen including the influential J. William Fulbright, but none was willing to make them public or hold hearings about them. So in March 1971 Ellsberg leaked the Pentagon Papers to the <em>New York Times<\/em>, which began publishing them three months later.<\/p> <p>When the Times was slapped with an injunction ordering a stop to publication, Ellsberg provided the Pentagon Papers to the <em>Washington Post<\/em> and then to 15 other newspapers. The case, entitled New York Times Co. v. The United States, ultimately went all the way to the United States Supreme Court, which on June 30, 1971 issued a landmark 6-3 decision authorizing the newspapers to print the Pentagon Papers without risk of government censure.<\/p><\/section> <section tml-anchor=\"life-as-a-whistleblower\"><h2>Life as a Whistleblower<\/h2><p>Not specifically because Ellsberg released the Pentagon Papers&mdash;which covered only the period up to 1968 and therefore did not implicate the Nixon administration&mdash;but rather because they feared, incorrectly, that Ellsberg possessed documents concerning Nixon's secret plans to escalate the Vietnam War (including contingency plans involving the use of nuclear weapons), Nixon and Kissinger embarked on a fanatical campaign to discredit him. An FBI agent named G. Gordon Liddy and a CIA operative named Howard Hunt&mdash;a duo dubbed \"the Plumbers\"&mdash;wiretapped Ellsberg's phone and broke into the office of his psychiatrist, Dr. Lewis Fielding, searching for materials with which to blackmail Ellsberg. Similar \"dirty tricks\" by \"the Plumbers\" eventually led to Nixon's downfall in the Watergate scandal.<\/p> <p>For leaking the Pentagon Papers, Ellsberg was charged with theft, conspiracy and violations of the Espionage Act, but his case was dismissed as a mistrial when evidence surfaced about the government-ordered wiretappings and break-ins.<\/p> <p>Ever since his leak of the Pentagon Papers, Ellsberg has remained active as a scholar and antiwar, anti-nuclear weapons activist. He has authored three books: <em>Papers on the War<\/em><em> <\/em>(1971), <em>Secrets: A Memoir of Vietnam and the Pentagon Papers<\/em> (2002) and <em>Risk, Ambiguity and Decision<\/em> (2001) as well as countless articles on economics, foreign policy and nuclear disarmament. In 2006, he received the Right Livelihood Award, known as the \"Alternative Nobel Prize,\" \"for putting peace and truth first, at considerable personal risk, and dedicating his life to inspiring others to follow his example.\"<\/p> <p>Daniel Ellsberg is married to Patricia Marx Ellsberg. He has three children and five grandchildren.<\/p> <p>When he chose to leak the Pentagon Papers in 1971, many people both within and outside the government derided him as a traitor and suspected him of espionage. Since that time, however, many have come to regard Daniel Ellsberg as hero of uncommon bravery, a man who risked his career and even his personal freedom to help expose the deception of his own government in carrying out the Vietnam War.<\/p> <p>The debate surrounding Ellsberg's leaking of the Pentagon Papers has recently regained international attention as historical context for the debate over the decision of Julian Assange, founder of WikiLeaks, to leak hundreds of thousands of secret diplomatic cables from U.S. embassies around the world. Ellsberg is an active and outspoken supporter of Assange's efforts. Ellsberg also remains fiercely proud of his decision to leak the Pentagon Papers, which he says not only deligitimized the Vietnam War, but also helped usher in a new era of skepticism about war and government in general.<\/p> <p>\"The Pentagon Papers definitely contributed to a delegitimation of the war, an impatience with its continuation, and a sense that it was wrong,\" Ellsberg said. \"They made people understand that presidents lie all the time, not just occasionally, but all the time. Not everything they say is a lie, but anything they say could be a lie.\"<\/p><\/section>","primaryImage":{"createdPrincipalId":"up016bb0b82173860f","height":402,"cloudinaryVersionId":1396471963,"id":"ci01ac7ce9e86a860c","objectType":"ContentPhoto","title":"Daniel-Ellsberg-17176398-1-402","primaryPhotoId":"ci01ac7ce9e86a860c","hasFaces":true,"width":402,"publicId":"MTE5NDg0MDU1MjYxMzgyMTU5","format":"jpg","createdTimestamp":"2014-04-02T20:52:44Z","primaryContentSiteId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e","bytes":47039,"primarySiteId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e"},"birthCountry":{"publicationTimestamp":"2014-04-02T04:18:20Z","createdPrincipalId":"up016bb0b82173860f","commentsEnabled":true,"id":"ci01a33b79f056860e","objectType":"ContentRichTerm","isNoindex":false,"title":"United States","authoringStatusCode":"in_progress","primaryImage":{"createdPrincipalId":"up016bb0b82173860f","height":402,"cloudinaryVersionId":1396412579,"id":"ci01a87e1d553f860f","objectType":"ContentPhoto","title":"Mildred-Loving-5884-1-402","primaryPhotoId":"ci01a87e1d553f860f","hasFaces":true,"width":402,"publicId":"MTE1ODA0OTcxMjQ4NzQ4MDQ1","format":"jpg","createdTimestamp":"2014-04-02T04:23:00Z","primaryContentSiteId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e","bytes":85862,"primarySiteId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e"},"vocabularyId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e:death_country","editedByPrincipalId":"up016bb0b82173860f","editedTimestamp":"2014-04-02T04:23:04Z","disqusId":"5da6a96c-ba1e-11e3-be79-002219604f34","originalPublicationTimestamp":"2014-04-02T04:19:16Z","createdTimestamp":"2014-04-02T04:23:04Z","versionId":"2","primaryImageId":"ci01a87e1d553f860f","path":"/people/groups/died-in-united-states","isWorkInProgress":false,"slug":"died-in-united-states","displayName":"United States","primaryContentSiteId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e","promoTitle":"Famous People Who Died in United States","primarySiteId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e","statusCode":"complete"},"birthCirca":false,"birthMonth":"5","metaDescription":"Pete Seeger was an iconic singer-songwriter best known for his contributions to the American folk music revival and his political activism. Learn more about his life and career at Biography.com.","editedTimestamp":"2014-04-02T19:43:48Z","deathState":{"publicationTimestamp":"2014-04-02T04:20:50Z","createdPrincipalId":"up016bb0b82173860f","commentsEnabled":true,"id":"ci01a87e1d5553860f","objectType":"ContentRichTerm","isNoindex":false,"title":"New York","authoringStatusCode":"in_progress","primaryImage":{"createdPrincipalId":"up016bb0b82173860f","height":402,"cloudinaryVersionId":1396412622,"id":"ci01a87e1d5551860f","objectType":"ContentPhoto","title":"Ben-Gazzara-6164-1-402","primaryPhotoId":"ci01a87e1d5551860f","hasFaces":true,"width":402,"publicId":"MTE5NDg0MDU0NTc1NzQ0NTI3","format":"jpg","createdTimestamp":"2014-04-02T04:23:43Z","primaryContentSiteId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e","bytes":55997,"primarySiteId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e"},"vocabularyId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e:death_state","editedByPrincipalId":"up016bb0b82173860f","editedTimestamp":"2014-04-02T04:23:47Z","disqusId":"95801e2c-ba1e-11e3-af8b-002219604f34","originalPublicationTimestamp":"2014-04-02T04:20:50Z","createdTimestamp":"2014-04-02T04:23:47Z","versionId":"1","primaryImageId":"ci01a87e1d5551860f","path":"/people/groups/died-in-new-york","isWorkInProgress":false,"slug":"died-in-new-york","displayName":"New York","primaryContentSiteId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e","promoTitle":"Famous People Who Died in New York","primarySiteId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e","statusCode":"complete"},"authoringStatusCode":"in_progress","profileTml":"<!-- tml-version=\"2\" --><section tml-anchor=\"synopsis\"><h2>Synopsis<\/h2><p>Born on May 3, 1919, Pete Seeger was an iconic singer-songwriter best known for his contributions to the American folk music revival and his political activism. He wrote hits like \"Where Have All the Flowers Gone?\" and \"Turn, Turn, Turn,\" which have since been recorded by several other artists. Seeger was also an engaged activist, supporting such causes as international disarmament, civil rights and environmental awareness. For his established career as a musician and activist, Seeger received three musical Grammy Awards and a Grammy Lifetime Achievement Award, among various other honors, during his lifetime. He died at age 94 on January 27, 2014, in New York City.<\/p><\/section><section tml-anchor=\"early-life\"><h2>Early Life<\/h2><p>American folk icon Peter Seeger was born in New York City on May 3, 1919, into a family of musicians. His father, Charles Seeger, taught music for some time at the University of California, Berkeley; and his mother, Constance (de Clyver Edson) Seeger, taught violin at the Juilliard School. Seeger's brother, Mike, would eventually become a member of New Lost City Ramblers; his sister, Peggy, would become a performing folk musician, alongside Ewan McColl.<\/p> <p>A precocious child, Seeger was well-read and began developing political and social ideas at an early age. After receiving an early education at Avon Old Farms, a Connecticut boarding school, Seeger enrolled at Harvard University on a scholarship in 1936. After only two years at Harvard, however, he failed an exam and lost his scholarship, so he dropped out. He spent the rest of the 1930s as a vagabond, hitchiking and riding on freight trains around the country.<\/p> <p>During this time, Seeger also focused on writing music. By 1940, he had organized a folk quartet called the Almanac Singers, which frequently featured Seeger's friend and fellow folk musician, Woody Guthrie. The Almanac Singers released several albums in the early '40s. In 1942, however, the group's musical progress was stopped short: Seeger was drafted into the Army to aid the country in battle during World War II, and the group disbanded not long after.<\/p> <p>In 1943, Seeger married Toshi Aline Ohta, whom he'd met at a dance in the late 1930s.<\/p><\/section> <section tml-anchor=\"musical-career\"><h2>Musical Career<\/h2><p>After the war ended, in 1945, Pete Seeger went back to his musical career, performing folk songs and helping found the magazine <em>Sing Out!<\/em> A few years later, in 1948, he formed the Weavers, which included Lee Hays, Ronnie Gilbert and Fred Hellerman. The group produced several albums of standard folk songs in the early 1950s&mdash;among them \"On Top of Old Smoky,\" \"Follow the Drinking Gourd\" and \"The Wreck of the John B\"&mdash;and even appeared in a 1951 film musical, <em>Disc Jockey<\/em>. The band also wrote and recorded several original songs, including \"If I Had a Hammer\" (1949) and \"Kisses Sweeter Than Wine\" (1950).<\/p> <p>The Weavers' success was halted, however, when speculation rose regarding Seeger's leftist political ideals, culminating with the band's designation as a Communist group by FBI informant Harvey Matusow (who later retracted his statement). The Weavers took a short break from 1952 to 1955&mdash;caused in large part by the negative press&mdash;and Seeger broke from the band in 1958. The group officially disbanded in 1962.<\/p> <p>The negative press surrounding Seeger and his politics deepened in 1961, when he was convicted for contempt of Congress&mdash;a judgment that was based on earlier questioning by the House Committee on Un-American Activities regarding Seeger's political activities as well as his subsequent and repeated refusal to answer to those claims. Seeger's musical career seemed even less promising following the conviction, which would be overturned in an appeal in 1962.<\/p> <p>Despite the controversy surrounding him, Seeger continued to perform and record as a solo artist during this time, producing such hit songs as \"Where Have All the Flowers Gone\" (1961) and \"Turn, Turn, Turn\" (1962), which was later released as a single by folk-rock group the Byrds on their album <em>Turn! Turn! Turn! <\/em>(1965).&nbsp;<\/p> <p>Also during this period, Seeger participated in the civil rights and anti-war movements of the '60s, and his reputation gradually improved. In 1966, Seeger recorded an anti-war anthem, \"Bring 'Em Home,\" including lyrics in opposition to the Vietnam War: \"For defense you need common sense/ Bring them home, bring them home/ They don't have the right armaments/ Bring them home, bring them home.\"  The song was later covered by Bruce Springsteen.<\/p> <p>His political activism bolstered Seeger's reputation as a college-campus icon and revered American folk musician. Following the release of several albums in the '60s, including <em>God Bless The Grass<\/em> and <em>Dangerous Songs!?<\/em> (both in 1966), Seeger published a literary, historical piece about folk music, civil rights and performers from the 20th century called <em>The Incompleat Folksinger<\/em> (1972).<\/p> <p>Throughout the rest of the '70s and into the '80s, the musician frequently performed with fellow folk singer-songwriter Arlo Guthrie, the son of folk legend Woody Guthrie. Also during this time, Seeger worked with other activists to remove pollution from the Hudson River and create the environmental organization Hudson River Sloop Clearwater, which, among many projects, hosts music festivals to help fund the river's maintenance.<\/p><\/section> <section tml-anchor=\"later-years-and-legacy\"><h2>Later Years and Legacy<\/h2><p>Seeger is regarded as a 20th century icon today, for his political activism as well as his pivotal role in the 1960s American folk  music revival. According to the <em>Encyclopedia of Folk, Country, and Western Music<\/em>,  Seeger was a \"father figure whose contributions as an artist and writer  were highly valued by people of all ages in and out of the music  field.\"<\/p> <p>Seeger received several high honors in the 1990s. In 1993, he received a Grammy Lifetime Achievement Award. He was awarded a National Medal of Arts a year later, and inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame in 1996. Following the release of his 1996 album, <em>Pete<\/em>, Seeger won a Grammy Award for best traditional folk album. That same year, he published an autobiography entitled <em>Where Have All the Flowers Gone<\/em>.<\/p> <p>Nearly a decade later, Seeger received his third Grammy Award&mdash;this time for best traditional album&mdash;for his 2008 release, <em>At 89<\/em>. Also in 2008, the folk icon performed at President Barack Obama's inaugural celebration. In 2010, at the age of 91, Seeger released the abum <em>Tomorrow's Children<\/em>, which he recorded with a group of students and dedicated to environmental awareness. The work garnered him his fourth Grammy Award, for best musical album for children.<\/p> <p>In his later years, Seeger continued to work as an activist, supporting such causes as international disarmament, civil rights  and environmental awareness. His wife, Toshi, passed away at the age of 91 on July 9, 2013&mdash;just days before the couple's 70th wedding anniversary&mdash;at their Beacon, New York, home. Seeger died months later, on January 27, 2014, at the age of 94, at New York Presbyterian Hospital in New York City. The legendary musician was survived by son Daniel, daughters Mika and Tinya, half-sister Peggy and six grandchildren.<\/p><\/section>","primaryImage":{"createdPrincipalId":"up016bb0b82173860f","height":402,"cloudinaryVersionId":1396467819,"id":"ci01ac7ce9e699860c","objectType":"ContentPhoto","title":"Pete-Seeger-9542618-1-402","primaryPhotoId":"ci01ac7ce9e699860c","hasFaces":false,"width":402,"publicId":"MTE5NTU2MzE2NDczMzYxOTMx","format":"jpg","createdTimestamp":"2014-04-02T19:43:41Z","primaryContentSiteId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e","bytes":173495,"primarySiteId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e"},"birthCountry":{"publicationTimestamp":"2014-04-02T04:18:20Z","createdPrincipalId":"up016bb0b82173860f","commentsEnabled":true,"id":"ci01a33b79f056860e","objectType":"ContentRichTerm","isNoindex":false,"title":"United Their music conveys universal truths and, in turbulent times, is often a call to action in the form of protest songs. Woody Guthrie, Bob Dylan, Joan Baez and other legendary folk singers have rallied audiences around historic causes such as the Civil Rights, peace and feminist movements. Here are some of the famous folk singers who were revolutionary through their songs.<\/p><p><\/p>\n<div tml-collection=\"ci01d0895bd002c80a\" tml-render-size=\"xlarge\" tml-render-style=\"slideshow\"><\/div>","slug":"folk-singers-and-folk-revolutionaries","displayName":"Folk Singers and Folk Revolutionaries","primaryContentSiteId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e","teaser":"With simply their voices and guitars, folk singers are the unplugged artists who tell our collective stories through their songs.","promoTitle":"Folk Singers and Folk Revolutionaries","dek":"With simply their voices and guitars, folk singers are the unplugged artists who tell our collective stories through their songs.","primarySiteId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e","statusCode":"complete"},{"publicationTimestamp":"2014-04-02T03:03:31Z","createdPrincipalId":"up016bb0b82173860f","commentsEnabled":true,"metaDescription":"Explore Biography's collection of famous people who were blacklisted. Hollywood was a major focus of the accusations, and after 10 actors refused to testify in front of the House Committee on Un-American Activities, the blacklist was created. Hundreds of actors, actresses, directors, screenwriters and other entertainment professionals were barred from working. Their music conveys universal truths and, in turbulent times, is often a call to action in the form of protest songs. Woody Guthrie, Bob Dylan, Joan Baez and other legendary folk singers have rallied audiences around historic causes such as the Civil Rights, peace and feminist movements. Hollywood was a major focus of the accusations, and after 10 actors refused to testify in front of the House Committee on Un-American Activities, the blacklist was created. Hundreds of actors, actresses, directors, screenwriters and other entertainment professionals were barred from working. Gifted vocalists have entertained audiences across musical genres from the tour de force arias of <a href=\"http://www.biography.com/people/luciano-pavarotti-9435296\">Luciano Pavarotti<\/a> to the classic crooning of <a href=\"http://www.biography.com/people/frank-sinatra-9484810\">Frank Sinatra<\/a> and <a href=\"http://www.biography.com/people/tony-bennett-9926699\">Tony Bennett<\/a> to the soulful vocals of artists like <a href=\"http://www.biography.com/people/aretha-franklin-9301157\">Aretha Franklin<\/a> and <a href=\"http://www.biography.com/people/mahalia-jackson-9351242\">Mahalia Jackson<\/a>. With their powerful lyricism, singers like <a href=\"http://www.biography.com/people/bob-dylan-9283052\">Bob Dylan<\/a>, <a href=\"http://www.biography.com/people/willie-nelson-9421488\">Willie Nelson<\/a> and <a href=\"http://www.biography.com/people/bruce-springsteen-9491214\">Bruce Springsteen<\/a> became poet laureates of American music while artists including <a href=\"http://www.biography.com/people/joan-baez-9195061\">Joan Baez<\/a> and <a href=\"http://www.biography.com/people/joe-strummer-248525\">Joe Strummer<\/a> used their voices to prompt social change while they entertained. Rockers from <a href=\"http://www.biography.com/people/elvis-presley-9446466\">Elvis Presley<\/a> to <a href=\"http://www.biography.com/people/groups/the-beatles\">The Beatles<\/a> to <a href=\"http://www.biography.com/people/kurt-cobain-9542179\">Kurt Cobain<\/a> helped define their generations through their songs while icons like <a href=\"http://www.biography.com/people/michael-jackson-38211\">Michael Jackson<\/a>, <a href=\"http://www.biography.com/people/cher-9246148\">Cher<\/a> and <a href=\"http://www.biography.com/people/whitney-houston-9344818\">Whitney Houston<\/a> shaped pop culture with their larger-than-life voices and personas. 1959, after Walk of Fame recording executives compiled a list of industry leaders who they realized would never get a star on Hollywood Boulevard, but deserved recognition. The group helped found the National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences, and named their award the \"Grammy\" as a nod to Edison's gramophone. Since then, hundreds of music industry members have received Grammys for their notable accomplishments in the field of music and recording.
