Moore","birthYear":{"publicationTimestamp":"2014-04-02T01:54:58Z","createdPrincipalId":"up016bb0b82173860f","commentsEnabled":true,"metaDescription":"Discover unexpected relationships between famous figures when you explore our group of famous people born in the year 1954.","id":"ci01a8bfd5f2d9860b","objectType":"ContentRichTerm","isNoindex":false,"title":"1954","authoringStatusCode":"in_progress","primaryImage":{"createdPrincipalId":"up016bb0b82173860f","height":2048,"cloudinaryVersionId":1396403868,"id":"ci01a87e1d4eed860f","objectType":"ContentPhoto","title":"Recep-Tayyip-Erdoan-37630-1-raw","primaryPhotoId":"ci01a87e1d4eed860f","hasFaces":true,"width":1582,"publicId":"MTE1ODA0OTcxMTU0NTcyODEz","format":"jpg","createdTimestamp":"2014-04-02T01:57:50Z","primaryContentSiteId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e","bytes":356299,"primarySiteId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e"},"vocabularyId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e:birth_year","editedByPrincipalId":"up016bb0b82173860f","editedTimestamp":"2014-04-02T01:57:51Z","disqusId":"323cee12-ba0a-11e3-a8a4-002219604f34","originalPublicationTimestamp":"2014-04-02T01:54:58Z","createdTimestamp":"2014-04-02T01:57:51Z","versionId":"1","primaryImageId":"ci01a87e1d4eed860f","path":"/people/groups/born-1954","isWorkInProgress":false,"overviewTml":"<!-- tml-version=\"2\" --><div tml-external-provider=\"brightcove\" tml-external-id=\"4495439099001:rkC8QsjOx:default:5336222452001:playlist:autoplay\" tml-embed-src=\"https://players.brightcove.net/4495439099001/rkC8QsjOx_default/index.html?playlistId=5336222452001&autoplay=true\"><\/div>\n        \n\n","slug":"born-1954","displayName":"1954","primaryContentSiteId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e","promoTitle":"Famous People Born in 1954","primarySiteId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e","statusCode":"complete"},"editedByPrincipalId":"up016bb0b82173860f","deathYearCe":true,"gender":"Male","birthCirca":false,"birthMonth":"4","metaDescription":"Visit Biography.com and follow the rabble-rousing career of Academy Award-winning documentary filmmaker and satirist, Michael Moore.","editedTimestamp":"2014-04-02T19:19:44Z","authoringStatusCode":"in_progress","profileTml":"<!-- tml-version=\"2\" --><section tml-anchor=\"synopsis\"><h2>Synopsis<\/h2><p>Michael Moore was born in Flint, Michigan on April 23, 1954. He started in print journalism and was briefly the editor of Mother Jones magazine. His debut film, Roger & Me, became the highest-grossing American documentary of all time. Moore had a short-lived political series called TV Nation and his film Bowling for Columbine, won an Academy Award. Moore lives in Traverse City, Michigan.<\/p><\/section><section tml-anchor=\"roger-&-me\"><h2>Roger & Me<\/h2><p>Writer, director, actor, political activist. Born in Flint, Michigan.  Moore burst onto the American cultural scene in the 1980s, a chubby,  extroverted rabble-rouser who hitched his political message to the  medium of satirical comedy in a crusade to rouse the national conscience  against corporate injustice. A genuine subversive, he made his impact  with his debut film, <em>Roger & Me<\/em> (1989), a satirical  documentary feature that chronicled his attempts to interview the CEO of  General Motors, Roger Smith. Moore wrote, directed and starred in the  film, which became the highest-grossing American documentary of all  time.<\/p><p>Critical opinion was high but divided. The <em>Washington Post<\/em> described <em>Roger & Me<\/em>  as a \"hilariously cranky bit of propaganda\" and critics such as Roger  Ebert gave it rave reviews, but others, including the doyenne of the <em>New Yorker,<\/em> Pauline Kael, attacked Moore for re-arranging the narrative events of the movie. He responded in an interview in <em>Film Comment<\/em>  that \"the movie is essentially what has happened to this town [Flint]  during the 1980s. I wasn't filming in 1982 ... so everything that  happened happened. As far as I'm concerned, a period of seven or eight  years ... is pretty immediate and pretty devastating.... I think it's a  document about a town that died in the 1980s.\" The critical controversy  notwithstanding, the film was voted Best Documentary by the National  Board of Review, the New York Film Critics, the Los Angeles Film  Critics, and the National Society of Film Critics, as well as Best Film  at the Toronto, Vancouver, and Chicago Film Festivals. It was included  on several critics' \"best of the decade\" lists, but conspicuously failed  even to be nominated for an Academy Award. <em>Roger & Me<\/em> was  creatively financed by Moore and his friends through bingo games and  other fund raising efforts, but also through an out of court settlement  Moore made with <em>Mother Jones<\/em> magazine over his dismissal from the publication after a short tenure as editor in 1986-87.<\/p><\/section> <section tml-anchor=\"background\"><h2>Background<\/h2><p>Moore came to <em>Mother Jones<\/em> after a successful career as an  alternative journalist in his hometown of Flint, Michigan (though he is  actually from the suburb of Davison). Moore's comedy and politics  emerged from his roots in a working-class community that enjoyed a boom  from manufacturing automobiles at a dozen General Motors factories until  the company abandoned the town, as chronicled in <em>Roger & Me.<\/em> Moore had been a staunch opponent of GM and local Flint politics since founding the <em>Flint Voice<\/em>  at the age of 22. He partially funded the newspaper through the weekly  showing of alternative movies, and promoted it through work on the local  public radio station where he hosted a show called \"Radio Free Flint.\"  He also wrote essays for National Public Radio. A rabble rouser from  early on, Moore was elected to his local school board at age 18 and  successfully fought to have its meetings open to the public.<\/p><\/section> <section tml-anchor=\"michael-moores-voice\"><h2>Michael Moore's Voice<\/h2><p>Moore followed up <em>Roger & Me<\/em> with a sequel, <em>Pets or Meat: A Return to Flint<\/em>  (1992) a short film shown on PBS. The second film repeated the narrated  style of the first and seemed more of a continuation than a sequel. In  it, Moore caught up on the lives of people from the first film,  including \"the Rabbit Lady,\" who sold rabbits as pets or meat. The film  was also an update on Moore himself, containing snippets from his  appearances on television talk shows such as Donahue<em>.<\/em> He made an  unlikely movie \"star\"—he is heavyset with a goofy grin, a fondness for  baseball caps, and a preference untucked shirts—yet there is no doubt  that the \"star\" of all of Moore's films is Michael Moore.<\/p><p>His next project was a narrative film, <em>Canadian Bacon<\/em>  (1994), starring John Candy, Rhea Perlman, Kevin Pollack, Alan Alda,  and Rip Torn. Alda plays a liberal U.S. president who decides to invade  Canada in order to boost his popularity in the polls. A cross between <em>Dr. Strangelove<\/em> (there's a similar Doomsday device) and <em>Wag the Dog<\/em>  (the invasion of a foreign country for shabby domestic reasons), the  film never received wide release, nor were the reviews particularly  enthusiastic.<\/p><\/section> <section tml-anchor=\"television-and-books\"><h2>Television and Books<\/h2><p>Moore's next move was to take the basic <em>Roger & Me<\/em> idea—good guy Mike harasses evil corporate America—to television. His political comedy show, <em>TV Nation<\/em>,  was a summer replacement on NBC in 1994. The show featured weekly,  off-the-wall polls like 16% of Perot voters believe that \"if dolphins  are really that smart they could get out of those nets,\" and showcased  memorable events such as a day of picnicking with \"Doctor Death\" Jack  Kevorkian. The first episode featured the \"CEO Challenge\" in which he  asked executives to perform menial tasks, such as getting the head of  IBM to format a disk. While not all the stories had a political bent, <em>TV Nation<\/em> was an eclectic mix of news magazine, sketch comedy, and David Letterman-style comedy of the banal. Only on <em>TV Nation<\/em>  would you see a guy in a Detroit Tigers baseball cap attempting to end  the conflict in Bosnia by getting leaders from the warring factions to  share a pizza together.<\/p><p>NBC passed on <em>TV Nation<\/em>, but Fox  picked it up for eight episodes in the summer of 1995. It was more of  the same, including a segment featuring Moore performing maneuvers with  the Michigan Militia. He also introduced Crackers, the corporate  crime-fighting chicken, alongside featured guests such as Merrill Markoe  (David Letterman's former chief writer), actress and stand-up comedian  Janeane Garofalo, former MTV VJ Karen Duffy, and filmmaker Rusty  Cundieff, who wrote and directed a comedy movie, <em>Fear of a Black Hat.<\/em> Moore chronicled his experiences with the show in a book, <em>Adventures in TV Nation<\/em> (1998), written with wife Kathleen Glynn.<\/p><p>The book was not his first. He had published <em>Downsize This: Random Threats from an Unarmed American,<\/em>  an unlikely best seller, in 1994. The book began with two photos: one  of the bombed out Federal building in Oklahoma City, the other of a pile  of rubble which used to be an auto factory in Flint. The point of that  piece, and the book, is to expose, through satire, irony, and  poke-in-the-eye comedy, corporate America's war on working-class  families. With chapters such as \"Would Pat Buchanan take a check from  Satan?\" \"Why doesn't GM sell crack?\" and \"Why are Union Leaders so  f#!&ing stupid?\" the book is part stand-up comedy in printed form,  part political manifesto, and part <em>Spy<\/em> magazine-like pranks. The  author embarked on an unconventional book promotion tour, refusing to  sign books at certain chain stores and seeking out independent  booksellers. After a few stops, he was joined by a film crew, which led  to the making of his movie <em>The Big One<\/em> (1997). The film features  stunts familiar to Moore's fans, including the presentation of Downsizer  of the Year awards to company bigwigs. It opened in selected cities as  benefits for local charities, unions, and leftist political groups.  Moore would answer questions, promote local causes, tell some jokes, and  then inspire the audience to political action. Despite excellent  reviews, <em>The Big One<\/em> failed to achieve commercial success; an  angry film about corporate America seemed out of synch when the Dow was  at an all-time record high.<\/p> <\/section> <section tml-anchor=\"provocative-documentaries\"><h2>Provocative Documentaries<\/h2><p>As the twentieth century ended, Moore was still pitching his  political message to a larger audience, attempting a weekly talk show  and developing <em>Better Days<\/em> (1998), a sitcom about a town where  everybody is unemployed. In conjunction with Britain's Channel 4, he  negotiated another incarnation of <em>TV Nation,<\/em> which launched in early 1999 under the title <em>The Awful Truth.<\/em>  It kicked off with a scathing attack on health insurance companies in  the United States and a somewhat crude and gauche sideswipe at Kenneth  Starr morality in the form of a sketch delivered like a scene from  Arthur Miller's <em>The Crucible.<\/em> Moore looked set to remain a viable  force in popular culture in the twenty-first century. Virtually the  country's lone left-wing satirist, he pops up regularly on talk shows  such as <em>Politically Incorrect.<\/em> Popular culture has never seen a  figure quite like Michael Moore: a comedian who one minute offers a  critical analysis of legislation, and in the next a suggestion that  Queen's \"We Will Rock You\" become the new national anthem.<\/p><p>In 2003, Moore's <em>Bowling for Columbine<\/em>,  which took a dark-comic look at gun culture in the United Sates, won  the Academy Award for Best Documentary Feature. The director's  acceptance speech included a very Moore-like statement against the war  with Iraq. \"We live in a time where we have a man sending us to war for  fictitious reasons. We are against this war, Mr. Bush. Shame on you!\"  The film was also awarded the Special 55th Anniversary Prize at the 2002  Cannes Film Festival. In late 2002, the director launched a one-man  stage show, <em>Michael Moore—Live<\/em>, in London and New York. In 2004, The Walt Disney Company banned Miramax from distributing Moore's documentary <em>Fahrenheit 9/11<\/em>,  which critiques the Bush administration's handling of Iraq and the war  on terror. The film won the coveted Palm d'Or at the Cannes Film  Festival and, when it eventually hit theaters in June, became the first  documentary to win the weekend box office.<\/p><\/section>","primaryImage":{"createdPrincipalId":"up016bb0b82173860f","height":402,"cloudinaryVersionId":1396466377,"id":"ci01a8bfd61d3d860b","objectType":"ContentPhoto","title":"Michael-Moore-9542483-1-402","primaryPhotoId":"ci01a8bfd61d3d860b","hasFaces":false,"width":402,"publicId":"MTIwNjA4NjM0MDU4MjEyODc2","format":"jpg","createdTimestamp":"2014-04-02T19:19:38Z","primaryContentSiteId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e","bytes":40565,"primarySiteId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e"},"birthCountry":{"publicationTimestamp":"2014-04-02T04:18:20Z","createdPrincipalId":"up016bb0b82173860f","commentsEnabled":true,"id":"ci01a33b79f056860e","objectType":"ContentRichTerm","isNoindex":false,"title":"United Here are a group of stars who got in shape despite the scrutiny of the press. Their efforts serve as an inspiration to the millions out there trying to live a healthier lifestyle.<\/p><p><\/p>\n<div tml-collection=\"ci01d0895bc005c80a\" tml-render-size=\"xlarge\" tml-render-style=\"slideshow\"><\/div>","slug":"weight-loss-winners","displayName":"Weight Loss Winners","primaryContentSiteId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e","teaser":"It's hard to face weight gain&mdash;but it's even harder to face it when the whole world is commenting on your expanding waistline.","promoTitle":"Weight Loss Winners","dek":"It's hard to face weight gain&mdash;but it's even harder to face it when the whole world is commenting on your expanding waistline.","primarySiteId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e","statusCode":"complete"},{"publicationTimestamp":"2014-04-02T03:21:21Z","createdPrincipalId":"up016bb0b82173860f","commentsEnabled":true,"metaDescription":"Explore Biography's collection of Famous Eagle Scouts See our picks, along with full biographies, photo galleries and videos, only on Biography.com. ","id":"ci01a33b79ee24860e","objectType":"ContentRichTerm","isNoindex":false,"title":"Eagle Scouts","authoringStatusCode":"in_progress","primaryImage":{"createdPrincipalId":"up016bb0b82173860f","height":1365,"cloudinaryVersionId":1396409054,"id":"ci01a8bfd5f68e860b","objectType":"ContentPhoto","title":"Peter-Agre-13503715-1-raw","primaryPhotoId":"ci01a8bfd5f68e860b","hasFaces":true,"width":2000,"publicId":"MTE1ODA0OTcxMjE2ODk3NTQ5","format":"jpg","createdTimestamp":"2014-04-02T03:24:16Z","primaryContentSiteId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e","bytes":376326,"primarySiteId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e"},"vocabularyId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e:groups","editedByPrincipalId":"up016bb0b82173860f","editedTimestamp":"2014-04-02T03:24:17Z","disqusId":"4554e674-ba16-11e3-ab56-002219604f34","originalPublicationTimestamp":"2014-04-02T03:21:21Z","createdTimestamp":"2014-04-02T03:24:17Z","versionId":"1","primaryImageId":"ci01a8bfd5f68e860b","path":"/people/groups/eagle-scouts","isWorkInProgress":false,"overviewTml":"<!-- tml-version=\"2\" --><div tml-external-provider=\"brightcove\" tml-external-id=\"4495439099001:rkC8QsjOx:default:5336653484001:playlist:autoplay\" tml-embed-src=\"https://players.brightcove.net/4495439099001/rkC8QsjOx_default/index.html?playlistId=5336653484001&autoplay=true\"><\/div>\n        \n<p>Incorporated in 1910, the Boy Scouts of America was founded with the aim of instilling ethics and morals into the lives of young boys. A Scout is a \"trustworthy, loyal, helpful, friendly, courteous, kind, obedient, cheerful, thrifty, brave, clean, and reverent,\" boy who, above all,  strives to \"be prepared\" and \"do his best.\" The highest order of these Boy Scouts are the Eagle Scouts, a rare group of young men who rise through the scouting ranks to earn 21 merit badges, serve for six months in a troop leadership position, and successfully complete a strict Eagle Scout board of review, among other requirements. <p><p> The first Eagle Scout to complete this training was 17-year-old Arthur R. Eldred, on September 2, 1912. Since then, more than 2 million Boy Scouts have earned the coveted rank. Here are some of the most famous of the honorable young men who made it to the top of the Boy Scouts program.<\/p><p><\/p>\n","slug":"eagle-scouts","displayName":"Eagle Scouts","primaryContentSiteId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e","teaser":"Incorporated in 1910, the Boy Scouts of America was founded with the aim of instilling ethics and morals into the lives of young boys.","promoTitle":"Eagle Scouts","dek":"Incorporated in 1910, the Boy Scouts of America was founded with the aim of instilling ethics and morals into the lives of young boys.","primarySiteId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e","statusCode":"complete"}],"path":"/people/michael-moore-9542483","isWorkInProgress":false,"slug":"michael-moore-9542483","primaryContentSiteId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e","lastName":{"publicationTimestamp":"2014-04-02T01:39:42Z","createdPrincipalId":"up016bb0b82173860f","commentsEnabled":true,"metaDescription":"Discover Moore.","id":"ci01a87e1d4db5860f","objectType":"ContentRichTerm","isNoindex":false,"title":"Moore","authoringStatusCode":"in_progress","primaryImage":{"createdPrincipalId":"up016bb0b82173860f","height":3000,"cloudinaryVersionId":1396402951,"id":"ci019b6c01f7c5860d","objectType":"ContentPhoto","title":"Pink-562098-1-raw","primaryPhotoId":"ci019b6c01f7c5860d","hasFaces":true,"width":2000,"publicId":"MTE5NDg0MDU0NDQ4MTQ1OTM1","format":"jpg","createdTimestamp":"2014-04-02T01:42:33Z","primaryContentSiteId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e","bytes":1069564,"primarySiteId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e"},"vocabularyId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e:last_name","editedByPrincipalId":"up016bb0b82173860f","editedTimestamp":"2014-04-02T01:42:35Z","disqusId":"1036ede2-ba08-11e3-a683-002219604f34","originalPublicationTimestamp":"2014-04-02T01:39:42Z","createdTimestamp":"2014-04-02T01:42:35Z","versionId":"1","primaryImageId":"ci019b6c01f7c5860d","path":"/people/groups/famous-named-moore","isWorkInProgress":false,"overviewTml":"<!-- tml-version=\"2\" --><div tml-external-provider=\"brightcove\" tml-external-id=\"4495439099001:rkC8QsjOx:default:5336505229001:playlist:autoplay\" tml-embed-src=\"https://players.brightcove.net/4495439099001/rkC8QsjOx_default/index.html?playlistId=5336505229001&autoplay=true\"><\/div>\n A Scout is a \"trustworthy, loyal, helpful, friendly, courteous, kind, obedient, cheerful, thrifty, brave, clean, and reverent,\" boy who, above all,  strives to \"be prepared\" and \"do his best.\" The highest order of these Boy Scouts are the Eagle Scouts, a rare group of young men who rise through the scouting ranks to earn 21 merit badges, serve for six months in a troop leadership position, and successfully complete a strict Eagle Scout board of review, among other requirements. <p><p> The first Eagle Scout to complete this training was 17-year-old Arthur R. Eldred, on September 2, 1912. Since then, more than 2 million Boy Scouts have earned the coveted rank. Here are some of the most famous of the honorable young men who made it to the top of the Boy Scouts program.<\/p><p><\/p>\n","slug":"eagle-scouts","displayName":"Eagle Serling, who created the sci-fi fantasy series 'The Twilight Zone,' on Biography.com.","editedTimestamp":"2014-04-02T16:09:06Z","deathState":{"publicationTimestamp":"2014-04-02T04:20:50Z","createdPrincipalId":"up016bb0b82173860f","commentsEnabled":true,"id":"ci01a87e1d5553860f","objectType":"ContentRichTerm","isNoindex":false,"title":"New York","authoringStatusCode":"in_progress","primaryImage":{"createdPrincipalId":"up016bb0b82173860f","height":402,"cloudinaryVersionId":1396412622,"id":"ci01a87e1d5551860f","objectType":"ContentPhoto","title":"Ben-Gazzara-6164-1-402","primaryPhotoId":"ci01a87e1d5551860f","hasFaces":true,"width":402,"publicId":"MTE5NDg0MDU0NTc1NzQ0NTI3","format":"jpg","createdTimestamp":"2014-04-02T04:23:43Z","primaryContentSiteId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e","bytes":55997,"primarySiteId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e"},"vocabularyId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e:death_state","editedByPrincipalId":"up016bb0b82173860f","editedTimestamp":"2014-04-02T04:23:47Z","disqusId":"95801e2c-ba1e-11e3-af8b-002219604f34","originalPublicationTimestamp":"2014-04-02T04:20:50Z","createdTimestamp":"2014-04-02T04:23:47Z","versionId":"1","primaryImageId":"ci01a87e1d5551860f","path":"/people/groups/died-in-new-york","isWorkInProgress":false,"slug":"died-in-new-york","displayName":"New York","primaryContentSiteId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e","promoTitle":"Famous People Who Died in New York","primarySiteId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e","statusCode":"complete"},"authoringStatusCode":"in_progress","profileTml":"<!-- tml-version=\"2\" --><section tml-anchor=\"synopsis\"><h2>Synopsis<\/h2><p>Rod Serling was born December 25, 1924, in Syracuse, New York. In 1955, he won his first Emmy, for writing the TV business drama <em>Patterns<\/em>. In 1959, he turned to the sci-fi fantasy genre, with <em>The Twilight Zone<\/em>. In 1968, he co-wrote the screenplay for <em>Planet of the Apes<\/em>. Serling died in Rochester, New York, on June 28, 1975. Over the course of his career, he wrote 252 scripts and won six Emmys.<\/p><\/section><section tml-anchor=\"early-years\"><h2>Early Years<\/h2><p>Television writer and producer Rod Serling was born Rodman Edward Serling on December 25, 1924, to a Jewish family in Syracuse, New York. When Serling was 2 years old, he and his family moved to the quiet college town of Binghamton, where his dad Sam opened a grocery store.<\/p><p>After graduating from Binghamton High School, Serling enlisted in the U.S. Army during World War II, with the aim of fighting the Nazis in Europe. Contrary to his intention, he ended up becoming a paratrooper in the Pacific theater. During the war, Serling was injured in his knee and wrist at the Battle of Leyte in the Philippines. He was sent home with a Purple Heart and emotional battle scars that would haunt him for the rest of his days.<\/p><p>To compound matters, Serling's return from the war was followed by the devastating loss of his father, who died suddenly of a heart attack. His traumatic experiences would later serve as inspiration for his writing. After the war, Serling attended Antioch College in Ohio.<\/p><\/section> <section tml-anchor=\"television-writer-and-producer\"><h2>Television Writer and Producer<\/h2><p>In 1948 Serling moved to New York City and entered the work world as a struggling freelance radio writer. In 1955, he branched out into television script writing with the TV business drama <em>Patterns<\/em>. <em>Patterns<\/em> earned Serling his first Emmy Award. <\/p><p>Serling's second Emmy win came a year later, with the 1956 production of <em>Requiem for a Heavyweight<\/em>, starring Jack Palance. During the late 1950s, Serling fought the CBS network when they insisted on editing his controversial scripts. CBS got its way and heavily revised his script about lynching, entitled <em>A Town Has Turned to Dust<\/em>, and another about corruption in a labor union, called <em>The Rank and File<\/em>. Instead of continuing to fight inevitable censorship, in 1959 Serling turned from realism to the sci-fi fantasy genre, with the iconic series <em>The Twilight Zone<\/em>. Not only did Serling write the series, but he was also the face of it, serving as its on-screen narrator. <em>The Twilight Zone<\/em> ran until 1964 and garnered Serling his third Emmy.<\/p><p>In 1968, Serling co-wrote the screenplay for the original movie version of <em>Planet of the Apes<\/em>. After a stint of screenwriting, he returned to television writing in 1970.<\/p><p>Serling spent his later career hosting <em>Rod Serling's Night Gallery<\/em> and teaching screenwriting at Ithaca College. Over the course of his career, Serling wrote an estimated 252 scripts and won a total of six Emmys.<\/p><\/section> <section tml-anchor=\"personal-life\"><h2>Personal Life<\/h2><p>While Serling worked 12 hours a day seven days a week, his wife, Carol, whom he had met at Antioch College, tended to their daughters, Jodi and Anne. Despite his demanding work schedule, Anne Serling claims in her memoir of her father, <em>As I Knew Him: My Dad, Rod Serling<\/em>, that she \"never felt the 12-hour workday,\" and always knew that if she needed to, she could go talk to him.<\/p><\/section> <section tml-anchor=\"later-life-and-death\"><h2>Later Life and Death<\/h2><p>In May of 1975, when he was 50 years old, Serling had a heart attack while running on a treadmill. A couple of weeks later, he had a second heart attack, at his cottage on Cayuga Lake, and was sent to the hospital for open-heart surgery. On June 28, 1975, Rod Serling died at Strong Memorial Hospital in Rochester, New tml-anchor=\"synopsis\"><h2>Synopsis<\/h2><p>American political activist Abbie Hoffman was born Nov. 30, 1936, in Worcester, Mass. He was active in the American civil rights movement before turning to protests of the Vietnam War and the American economic and political system. Hoffman's ethic was codified with the formal organization of the Yippies in January 1968. After he was arrested in 1973 on cocaine charges, Hoffman went tml-anchor=\"synopsis\"><h2>Synopsis<\/h2><p>Joseph Heller was born May 1, 1923 in Brooklyn, New York. He flew 60 combat missions as a bombardier in World War II before finishing his studies at Columbia and Oxford and working as an advertising copywriter. His satirical novel <em>Catch-22<\/em> (1961), based on his wartime experiences, was one of the most significant works of postwar protest literature and a huge critical and popular of Massachusetts at Amherst","authoringStatusCode":"in_progress","primaryImage":{"createdPrincipalId":"up016bb0b82173860f","height":402,"cloudinaryVersionId":1396439330,"id":"ci01ac7ce9d7eb860c","objectType":"ContentPhoto","title":"Richard-Gere-9309229-1-402(2)","primaryPhotoId":"ci01ac7ce9d7eb860c","hasFaces":true,"width":402,"publicId":"MTE4MDAzNDEwNTM1Mjg2Mjg2","format":"jpg","createdTimestamp":"2014-04-02T11:48:51Z","primaryContentSiteId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e","bytes":40599,"primarySiteId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e"},"vocabularyId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e:schools","editedByPrincipalId":"up016bb0b82173860f","editedTimestamp":"2014-04-02T11:48:55Z","disqusId":"c4fba64c-ba5c-11e3-a663-002219604f34","originalPublicationTimestamp":"2014-04-02T11:45:46Z","createdTimestamp":"2014-04-02T11:48:55Z","versionId":"1","primaryImageId":"ci01ac7ce9d7eb860c","path":"/people/groups/famous-alumni-of-university-of-massachusetts-at-amherst","isWorkInProgress":false,"slug":"famous-alumni-of-university-of-massachusetts-at-amherst","displayName":"University of Massachusetts at Amherst","primaryContentSiteId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e","promoTitle":"Famous University of Massachusetts at Amherst Alumni","primarySiteId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e","statusCode":"complete"}],"deathYearCe":true,"gender":"Male","birthCirca":false,"birthMonth":"8","metaDescription":"Richard Gere has been a sex symbol in American media for more than 30 years. Learn more about his life, career and loves at Biography.com.","editedTimestamp":"2014-04-02T11:48:58Z","authoringStatusCode":"in_progress","profileTml":"<!-- tml-version=\"2\" --><section tml-anchor=\"synopsis\"><h2>Synopsis<\/h2><p>Born in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, on August 31, 1949, Richard Gere studied at the University of Massachusetts, became a pop musician, and went on to gain extensive experience as a stage actor. Gere received acclaim for an off-Broadway appearance in <em>Killer's Head<\/em>, then made his big-screen debut with a small role in <em>Report to the Commissioner<\/em>. His other films include <em>Yanks<\/em>, <em>American Gigolo<\/em>, <em>An Officer and A Gentleman<\/em>, <em>Pretty Woman<\/em>, <em>Chicago<\/em> and <em>Shall We Dance?<\/em>.<\/p><\/section>\n<div tml-anchor=\"image-richard-gere-9309229-1-raw\">\n    <div tml-image=\"ci01a33b7a073c860e\" tml-image-caption=\"\"><\/div>\n<\/div>        \n        <section tml-anchor=\"early-life-and-career\"><h2>Early Life and Career<\/h2><p>Born on August 31, 1949, in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, actor Richard Tiffany Gere has made a name for himself with such films as <em>An Officer and a Gentleman<\/em>, <em>Pretty Woman<\/em>, <em>Chicago<\/em> and <em>Arbitrage<\/em>. He grew up in a large Methodist family, one of five children born to Homer and Doris Ann Gere. A musical child, Gere became quite skilled at playing the trumpet.<\/p> <p>After graduating from North Syracuse Central High School in 1967, Richard Gere studied philosophy at University of Massachusetts at Amherst on a gymnastics scholarship. He left school after two years to explore his interest in theater. In the early 1970s, Gere landed the role of Danny Zuko in the musical <em>Grease<\/em> in London.<\/p> <p>Gere had a career breakthrough in 1977 with the dramatic thriller <em>Looking for Mr. Goodbar<\/em>, starring Diane Keaton. In the film, he plays a rough-and-tumble lothario who meets a schoolteacher (Keaton). The following year, Gere landed a starring role in Terrence Malick's epic <em>Days of Heaven<\/em>.<\/p><\/section> <section tml-anchor=\"hollywoods-leading-man\"><h2>Hollywood's Leading Man<\/h2><p>Gere became an actor on the rise in the 1980s. In 1980, he had the title role in <em>American Gigolo<\/em>. Gere's character in the film is the personification of smooth and cool with his distinctive fashion style and swagger. Two years later, he came to embody the romantic lead in <em>An Officer and a Gentleman<\/em> opposite Debra Winger. Gere plays a troubled military recruit who gets involved with a local girl near his basic training camp. The drama proved to be a box office hit.<\/p> <p>In 1990, Gere enjoyed another wave of success with the romantic comedy <em>Pretty Woman<\/em>. The film follows the unlikely relationship that develops between a prostitute, played by Julia Roberts, and her client (Gere). He also showed himself capable of handling more weighty roles, such as the dirty cop in 1990's <em>Internal Affairs<\/em> and a defense attorney in <em>Primal Fear<\/em> (1996).<\/p> <p>Known for his charisma, charm and good looks, Gere earned <em>People<\/em> magazine's \"Sexiest Man Alive\" honor in 1999. He played against type for 2002's <em>Unfaithful<\/em> as Diane Lane's cuckolded husband. That same year, Gere returned to his musical theater roots with the film adaptation of the Broadway hit <em>Chicago<\/em>. He won a Golden Globe Award for his portrayal of slick lawyer Billy Flynn.<\/p><\/section> <section tml-anchor=\"activist-actor\"><h2>Activist Actor<\/h2><p>Throughout his career, Gere has devoted much of his time to his social and political causes. The longtime Buddhist co-founded the Tibet House in 1987 and has served as the chairman of the board for the International Campaign for Tibet since 1995. He later established the Gere Foundation \"to help sponsor human rights in Tibet and support the Dalai Lama,\" Gere explained to <em>Redbook<\/em>. He also supported charities to help those suffering from AIDS, especially in India.<\/p> <p>These days Gere divides his time between his activism and his acting. He still seeks out interesting characters to play on the big screen. He starred in 2006's <em>The Hoax<\/em> as the infamous writer Clifford Irving. Irving conned the world into believing he wrote a biography of famed reclusive business mogul Howard Hughes in the 1970s. The following year, Gere appeared in <em>I'm Not There<\/em>, an experimental film about music legend Bob Dylan. He also reunited with Diane Lane for the romantic drama <em>Nights in Rodanthe<\/em> (2008) around this time.<\/p> <p>In 2009, Gere co-starred with Hilary Swank in <em>Amelia<\/em>, a biopic about groundbreaking aviator Amelia Earhart. While that film proved to be a critical and commercial disappointment, he earned raves for one of his next efforts. Gere starred in 2012's <em>Arbitrage<\/em> with Susan Sarandon, playing a troubled hedge fund titan; his stunning performance in the film earned him a Golden Globe Award nomination.<\/p><\/section> <section tml-anchor=\"personal-life\"><h2>Personal Life<\/h2><p>Gere was married to model Cindy Crawford from 1991 to 1995.<\/p> <p>In 2002, Gere wed actress Carey Lowell; they have one child together, a son named Homer. Gere and Lowell lived together in Bedford, New York, for many years. There they also co-owned the Bedford Post Inn with Russell Hernandez. In September 2013, Gere and Lowell announced that they were separating.<\/p><\/section>","primaryImage":{"createdPrincipalId":"up016bb0b82173860f","height":402,"cloudinaryVersionId":1396439330,"id":"ci01ac7ce9d7eb860c","objectType":"ContentPhoto","title":"Richard-Gere-9309229-1-402(2)","primaryPhotoId":"ci01ac7ce9d7eb860c","hasFaces":true,"width":402,"publicId":"MTE4MDAzNDEwNTM1Mjg2Mjg2","format":"jpg","createdTimestamp":"2014-04-02T11:48:51Z","primaryContentSiteId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e","bytes":40599,"primarySiteId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e"},"birthCountry":{"publicationTimestamp":"2014-04-02T04:18:20Z","createdPrincipalId":"up016bb0b82173860f","commentsEnabled":true,"id":"ci01a33b79f056860e","objectType":"ContentRichTerm","isNoindex":false,"title":"United tml-anchor=\"synopsis\"><h2>Synopsis<\/h2><p>French jurist and lawyer Ren&eacute; Cassin, born on October 5, 1887, in Bayonne, France, was the president of the European Court of Human Rights and is best known for his involvement in the drafting of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights. After the fall of France in June 1940, he joined General Charles de Gaulle in London and served as a key member of the Free French government in exile. Cassin won the Nobel Prize for Peace in 1968.<\/p><\/section>","primaryImage":{"createdPrincipalId":"up016bb0b82173860f","height":402,"cloudinaryVersionId":1396433502,"id":"ci01a87e1d69a1860f","objectType":"ContentPhoto","title":"Rene-Cassini-9240978-1-402","primaryPhotoId":"ci01a87e1d69a1860f","hasFaces":true,"width":402,"publicId":"MTE5NTU2MzE2MTc5MTA1Mjkx","format":"jpg","createdTimestamp":"2014-04-02T10:11:43Z","primaryContentSiteId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e","bytes":39694,"primarySiteId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e"},"birthCountry":{"publicationTimestamp":"2014-04-02T04:28:44Z","createdPrincipalId":"up016bb0b82173860f","commentsEnabled":true,"id":"ci01a33b79f0b0860e","objectType":"ContentRichTerm","isNoindex":false,"title":"France","authoringStatusCode":"in_progress","primaryImage":{"createdPrincipalId":"up016bb0b82173860f","height":402,"cloudinaryVersionId":1396413096,"id":"ci01a87e1d55c9860f","objectType":"ContentPhoto","title":"Roland-Barthes-36995-1-402","primaryPhotoId":"ci01a87e1d55c9860f","hasFaces":true,"width":402,"publicId":"MTE5NDg0MDU0NTgzNjA4ODQ3","format":"jpg","createdTimestamp":"2014-04-02T04:31:37Z","primaryContentSiteId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e","bytes":46053,"primarySiteId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e"},"vocabularyId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e:birth_country","editedByPrincipalId":"up016bb0b82173860f","editedTimestamp":"2014-04-02T04:31:41Z","disqusId":"afd4a8fa-ba1f-11e3-bced-002219604f34","originalPublicationTimestamp":"2014-04-02T04:28:44Z","createdTimestamp":"2014-04-02T04:31:41Z","versionId":"1","primaryImageId":"ci01a87e1d55c9860f","path":"/people/groups/born-in-france","isWorkInProgress":false,"slug":"born-in-france","displayName":"France","primaryContentSiteId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e","promoTitle":"Famous People Born in France","primarySiteId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e","statusCode":"complete"},"bestKnownFor":"French jurist and lawyer Ren&eacute; Historians believe Alfred Nobel wanted to award people who work for peace to compensate for his own role in inventing dynamite. Since its establishment, the prize has gone to many courageous individuals who have fought for peace and human rights around the roles as a film star, but will forever be known for his James Bond portrayal. Learn more at Biography.com.","editedTimestamp":"2014-04-02T09:52:42Z","authoringStatusCode":"in_progress","profileTml":"<!-- tml-version=\"2\" --><section tml-anchor=\"synopsis\"><h2>Synopsis<\/h2><p>Irish actor Pierce Brosnan, born on May 16, 1953, first won over American television audiences in the detective series <em>Remington Steele<\/em>, which debuted in 1982. Today, he's best known for his recurring role as the famous British spy James Bond in the film series of the same name, following in the footsteps of actors like Sean Connery and Roger Moore. Outside of<em> Bond<\/em>, Brosnan is known for big-screen performances in <em>The Thomas Crown Affair<\/em>, <em>Laws of Attraction<\/em> and <em>Mrs. Doubtfire<\/em>.<\/p><\/section><section tml-anchor=\"early-acting-career\"><h2>Early Acting Career<\/h2><p>Pierce Brendan Brosnan was born on May 16, 1953, in Drogheda, County Louth, Ireland. After an unsettled childhood, Brosnan moved to London, where he joined an experimental theater group and studied at the Drama Centre. After several stage roles in London, he moved to Los Angeles, where he was offered the lead in the detective series <em>Remington Steele<\/em>, which debuted in 1982.<\/p> <p>Brosnan won over American television audiences with his <em>Remington Steele <\/em>performance, which brought deserved attention to his good looks and charm. Viewers tuned in to catch the show's latest mystery and watch the sparks fly between the two lead characters, played by Brosnan and his co-star, Stephanie Zimbalist.<\/p><\/section> <section tml-anchor=\"james-bond-star\"><h2>'James Bond' Star<\/h2><p>When he received an offer in 1986 to play the famous British spy James Bond&mdash;of the film series of the same name&mdash;Pierce Brosnan tried to get out of his contract for <em>Remington Steele<\/em>, but to no avail.  The TV series ended the following year.<\/p> <p>In the late '80s, Brosnan acted in several television and film projects, including the TV miniseries <em>Around the World in 80 Days<\/em> (1989), and the hit comedy film <em>Mrs. Doubtfire<\/em> (1993). In 1995, Brosnan finally secured a role as the legendary James Bond in <em>Goldeneye<\/em>, following in the footsteps of actors like Sean Connery and Roger Moore. He played Bond three more times, in 1997's <em>Tomorrow Never Dies<\/em>, 1999's <em>The World is Not Enough<\/em> and 2002's <em>Die Another Day<\/em>.<\/p> <p>After starring in four <em><i>James <\/em>Bond<\/i> films, Brosnan decided it was time to pass the baton: Actor Daniel Craig took over the part in 2006&mdash;four years after the release of <em>Die Another Day<\/em>&mdash;in a remake of the first<em> Bond<\/em> picture, <em>Casino Royale<\/em>.<\/p> <p>Outside of playing the smooth but deadly superspy, Brosnan has tackled several dramatic and comedic roles. He has appeared in such films as 1999's <em>The Thomas Crown Affair<\/em>, with Rene Russo; 2004's <em>Laws of Attraction<\/em>, starring alongside Julianne Moore; and 2005's <em>The Matador<\/em>, with Greg Kinnear, among other big-screen productions. Since the comedy smash <em>Mrs. Doubtfire <\/em>was released in 1993, media reports have speculated on a potential sequel&mdash;in which Brosnan would most likely appear.<\/p><\/section> <section tml-anchor=\"personal-life\"><h2>Personal Life<\/h2><p>Brosnan has been married twice. His first marriage to actress  Cassandra Harris lasted from 1980 until her death in 1991. He  adopted her two children, Charlotte and Christopher, and the couple had a  son together, Sean. In 2001, Brosnan married Keely Shaye. They have two children  together, Paris and Dylan.<\/p><\/section>","primaryImage":{"createdPrincipalId":"up016bb0b82173860f","height":402,"cloudinaryVersionId":1396432353,"id":"ci01a8bfd60bbd860b","objectType":"ContentPhoto","title":"Pierce-Brosnan-9227805-402","primaryPhotoId":"ci01a8bfd60bbd860b","hasFaces":true,"width":402,"publicId":"MTIwNjA4NjMzNzU0NTg0NTg4","format":"jpg","createdTimestamp":"2014-04-02T09:52:34Z","primaryContentSiteId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e","bytes":48370,"primarySiteId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e"},"birthCountry":{"publicationTimestamp":"2014-04-02T06:26:52Z","createdPrincipalId":"up016bb0b82173860f","commentsEnabled":true,"id":"ci01a33b79f839860e","objectType":"ContentRichTerm","isNoindex":false,"title":"Ireland","authoringStatusCode":"in_progress","primaryImage":{"createdPrincipalId":"up016bb0b82173860f","height":402,"cloudinaryVersionId":1396420187,"id":"ci01ac7ce9c878860c","objectType":"ContentPhoto","title":"Darren-Clarke-193223-1-402","primaryPhotoId":"ci01ac7ce9c878860c","hasFaces":true,"width":402,"publicId":"MTE5NTU2MzE1OTgyNjkzODk5","format":"jpg","createdTimestamp":"2014-04-02T06:29:49Z","primaryContentSiteId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e","bytes":60287,"primarySiteId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e"},"vocabularyId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e:birth_country","editedByPrincipalId":"up016bb0b82173860f","editedTimestamp":"2014-04-02T06:29:53Z","disqusId":"33134d7e-ba30-11e3-992e-002219604f34","originalPublicationTimestamp":"2014-04-02T06:26:52Z","createdTimestamp":"2014-04-02T06:29:53Z","versionId":"1","primaryImageId":"ci01ac7ce9c878860c","path":"/people/groups/born-in-ireland","isWorkInProgress":false,"slug":"born-in-ireland","displayName":"Ireland","primaryContentSiteId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e","promoTitle":"Famous Sean Connery, the first actor to play James Bond, embodied the role of the be-tuxed international spy who thwarts international baddies in service to Her Majesty. Connery starred in seven <em>Bond<\/em> films and passed the keys to Bond's Aston Martin to Australian actor/model George Lazenby (who played Bond in only one film, <em>On Her Majesty's Secret Service<\/em>) followed by other actors who played the role including Roger Moore, Timothy Dalton, Pierce Brosnan and Daniel Craig. People Who Died in Virginia","primarySiteId":"cs01a33b78d5c5860e","statusCode":"complete"},"authoringStatusCode":"in_progress","profileTml":"<!-- tml-version=\"2\" --><section tml-anchor=\"synopsis\"><h2>Synopsis<\/h2><p>John Murtha was born June 17, 1932, in New Martinsville, West Virginia. In 1969, he was elected to the Pennsylvania House. He served in Pennsylvania until 1974, when he was appointed to the U.S. House of Representatives in a special election to fill a vacancy caused by the death of GOP Rep. John P. Saylor. Murtha served in the House until his death in 2010.<\/p><\/section><section tml-anchor=\"profile\"><h2>Profile<\/h2><p>Politician. Born June 17, 1932, in New Martinsville, West Virginia. John Patrick Murtha's family had a deep military history; his great-grandfather served in the Civil War and his father and three uncles in World War II. In 1962, Murtha received a bachelor's degree in economics from the University of Pittsburgh. He then completed graduate courses at Indiana University of Pennsylvania.<\/p> <p>In 1966, as the Vietnam war escalated, Murtha volunteered for active duty in the Marines, joining his brothers  in the military. Wounded twice, he was awarded two Purple Hearts, a Bronze Star and the Vietnamese Cross of Gallantry. Upon his return to the United States, he entered politics. In 1969, he was elected to the Pennsylvania House. He served in Pennsylvania until 1974, when he was appointed to the U.S. House of Representatives in a special election to fill a vacancy caused by the death of GOP Rep. John P. Saylor.<\/p> <p>Murtha served in the House until his death in 2010. During his time in office, Murtha chaired the House Appropriations Defense Subcommittee. He also became a critic of the Iraq war, calling it unwinable. He pushed the Bush administration to commit more troops and resources. <\/p> <p>The congressman died on the afternoon of February 8, 2010, in the Virginia Hospital Center in Arlington, Virginia, after complications from gall bladder surgery. <\/p> <P>Murtha and his wife, Joyce, lived in Washinton, D.C. with their three children until his death in 2010.<\/p> A Scout is a \"trustworthy, loyal, helpful, friendly, courteous, kind, obedient, cheerful, thrifty, brave, clean, and reverent,\" boy who, above all,  strives to \"be prepared\" and \"do his best.\" The highest order of these Boy Scouts are the Eagle Scouts, a rare group of young men who rise through the scouting ranks to earn 21 merit badges, serve for six months in a troop leadership position, and successfully complete a strict Eagle Scout board of review, among other requirements. <p><p> The first Eagle Scout to complete this training was 17-year-old Arthur R. Eldred, on September 2, 1912. Since then, more than 2 million Boy Scouts have earned the coveted rank. A Scout is a \"trustworthy, loyal, helpful, friendly, courteous, kind, obedient, cheerful, thrifty, brave, clean, and reverent,\" boy who, above all,  strives to \"be prepared\" and \"do his best.\" The highest order of these Boy Scouts are the Eagle Scouts, a rare group of young men who rise through the scouting ranks to earn 21 merit badges, serve for six months in a troop leadership position, and successfully complete a strict Eagle Scout board of review, among other requirements. <p><p> The first Eagle Scout to complete this training was 17-year-old Arthur R. Eldred, on September 2, 1912. Since then, more than 2 million Boy Scouts have earned the coveted rank.
